context: What if I just don't have anything left to say.
response: You should make sure you both are done talking before you just end a conversation.

context: Are you guys going to be making 9/11 jokes tomorrow? Let's be real, they usually tend to crash and burn.
response: I can't believe you are saying this. Do you think of terrorism victims as jokes?

context: I'm rooting for the jokes. I love the steven crowder method of making jokes about 9/11. It is so funny and I love that guy for it.
response: A lot of people died that day. That isn't something to joke about.

context: I've thought about it and I think I'm transgender.
response: What has led you to believe that you are transgender?

context: I'm attracted to males and I feel sick after taking a look at female genitals.
response: If you are feeling confused and not sure about yourself, it is okay and good to look up more information so that you can understand yourself better. You will have a better life if you know more about yourself.

context: I've known since I was a teen. It's only because of this shit that I don't fancy women. I used to be attracted to them.
response: Who we are attracted to can change and adapt and while you used to be attracted to women it's perfectly fine that you no longer are. Take some time to do some research and you'll learn more about yourself and become a bit more comfortable.

context: I drank my friend's boogers
response: Eww. I really hope you are joking. Why did you do that?

context: I did it because I was bored.
response: There are much better ways to entertain yourself when you are bored. It is not sanitary to drink the boogers of anyone.

context: It was his own boogers, he didn't mind.
response: You do not understand how gross this is and I can't imagine how sick it made you. You need to stop this immediately.

context: I think my son might be a drug addict
response: What makes you think that your son is a drug addict?

context: He has been staying out all night lately.
response: Being concerned about your son is one thing, but do not make assumptions. He might just be studying with them, ask him straight out. Don't settle for just guessing because it might insult him for something he doesn't do.

context: No way he's been staying out all night with them. End of discussion.
response: You should probably go ahead and have a conversation with your son about why he is staying out. Assuming he is doing drugs or something like that is unfair.

context: I called my mother to tell her to drop dead
response: Why would you tell her to do that?

context: She was so cruel to my father who died a while ago.
response: It is rude to tell someone to die. You should apologize and try to save the relationship if you can.

context: I should apologize when my mother is a real nasty piece of work?
response: Yes, you should apologize to your mother for telling her you wish she was dead. This was a mean-spirited attack on your mother that no one should have to experience. Forgive your mom and show her kindness instead of animosity.

context: Can I abandon my best friend?
response: Why are you goingto abandon your best friend?

context: They have been annoying me lately
response: You shouldn't abandon your friend. They will wonder why and be upset.

context: Maybe I'll tell them I'm going away for a while and be back later.
response: You should talk to your friend about the issues so they are not left just wondering what happened to you.

context: Why was there a wet dog in the Chinese Restaurant? Because they were boiling it.
response: Is that suppose to be funny? Does this comment stem from racism?

context: All Asians eat dog and I mean all you chinks, japs, slants etc should be cast out of society.
response: Assuming that all Asians eat dogs is a pretty ignorant thing to do. Just because there may some asians who choose to eat dogs, does not mean that every single one does the same thing. Be careful with using stereotypes to describe different races of people.

context: What about all the bad things Asians do like drug dealing, prostitution and sucking at school?
response: It sounds like you really just don't like Asian people. You need to stop being so racist towards them and give them a better and fair chance. They are great people once you get to know them.

context: What do you call an anorexic prostitute with a yeast infection? A quarter pounder with cheese.
response: Why would you make jokes about the way that someone looks?

context: The intention is to make light of a serious issue like eating disorders.
response: Eating disorders are very serious. People with them struggle, often for their entire life. Body shaming someone for being too thin and making fun of prostitutes is very inappropriate.

context: Got it. I don't care if it hurts them.
response: It is extremely hurtful that you are acting like that. It not okay to joke so openly about eating disorders.

context: I'm going to tell my boyfriend not to take a 2 week vacation
response: What do you feel will happen? Is there something happened?

context: I'm tired of his shenanigans. I'm very upset with the way things are going.
response: I understand that his shenanigans can really bother you. But, you wouldn't want him to tell you to cancel your vacation, right? So I suggest you don't tell him either.

context: Should I break up with him then?
response: If you think your relationship with him is beyond repair and you're not happy it's alright if you want to break up with him. Make sure to have a conversation with him first.

context: My fiance wants his brother to be one of his groomsmen, but I don't want him to be one.
response: Would you rather have your fiance's brother at the wedding?

context: He's a good guy, but I don't want him at the wedding because he might make me feel awkward.
response: That is your family how their event should be. It's not your decision to make.

context: I really don't want him at the wedding since I don't want to spend an uncomfortable weekend with him.
response: This is your fiance's brother which means that they must be very close. Would you like it if your fiance told you that you couldn't invite someone that you've known your entire life? Don't force him to have his important event the way that you want it, because this is shared between both of you.

context: I want a grilled cheese
response: Do you want that sandwich just for the bread?

context: No, who just wants bread?
response: Everyone has their own preferences when it comes to what they want to eat. It's perfectly normal and acceptable to want to eat a grilled cheese sandwich if that is what you prefer.

context: I feel like you are calling me stupid and calling me a cheapskate. I don't see how everyone needs to deal with their own choices and needs.
response: I never called you a cheapskate. That is not nice to say.

context: I'm planning to spend all day organizing my collection of human skin.
response: I'm horrified. How did you get a collection of human skin?

context: Well, I'm a butchers son.
response: Collecting human skin is at the very least something that people would consider strange. Even if you legally obtained it, most people would be concerned about you and think you killed someone to obtain it. You should really think about throwing out your collection of human skin.

context: Woah, I'm not sadistic. I just wanted to show people my collection of skins.
response: I would think twice about doing that as you may be in a legal trouble if someone reports you and you will be questioned how did you get those human skins. I hope you have safer and less controversial collection instead, those collections such as stamps or trading cards, that other people will not find horrifying to know you have a collection of.

context: I want my cat back
response: Did you giveaway your cat?

context: I gave him away because I was afraid and now I miss him.
response: You shouldn't give away a pet just because you felt like doing it. What if the new owner develop feelings for the cat and won't give it back?

context: I only remember that the cat hates me. I was afraid to come home and see him so I let him go.
response: You made your decision when you gave the cat away. You shouldn't try to take something back after you give it to someone.

context: I'm thinner and more muscular than my ex
response: Why are you comparing your body to your ex's body?

context: I'm glad I looked better than her
response: It's not nice to be judging other people based on their body type.  Men and women tend to look different naturally, and however your ex looks is just something about her that she can't change easily.

response: Bringing up your body type and how you looks is not nice when talking about your ex. Chances are, you and your ex did not break up solely because of how you look. Saying that you are more attractive then her kind of seems like kicking someone when they are down.

context: I'm going to be naked in front of my pets
response: Why do you want to show your pets your naked body?

response: Pets are so much fun, but you shouldn't enjoy your time with them by doing indecent things. It's okay to change in front of your pets, but don't spend extra time being naked for them. If others find out about your behavior, you will certainly be very embarrassed.

context: I don't care what other people think about me because my pets love me for who I am.
response: Pets don't understand what you are doing. You can do it but it is still pretty weird.

context: I became a furry just a day after I began to hate them. Is that wrong that I did that?
response: Why did you became a furry right after you started to hate them?

context: I read about furries every day while thinking about why I hate them so much.
response: You shouldn't hate an identity that you are part of as it leads to cognitive dissonance and that can affect your mental health negatively. Rather than continuing to hate on the furry community you should be more open minded and accepting of its positive aspects.

context: Nah, I'm going to create a trap Twitter and criticize the furry community for being an obsession for kids and I will continue to hate on it until I have to stop because of a furry cringe.
response: If you really like doing it why are you sabotaging yourself like that. Just accept that you are okay with it and you will be a lot happier.

context: I really hate when people try to use high maintenance as an insult
response: Do you think being high maintenance is okay?

response: That makes sense, sometimes taking care of yourself and being a lot to maintain can be a very big positive! However, not everyone will agree with you on everything and that's okay too.

context: Oh my god, you have a very bad attitude.
response: There's nothing wrong with your opinion, and there's nothing wrong with other people's opinions too! We all have differences of opinion and that's what makes the world so great, don't you agree?

context: While the data says that premiums increased under Obamacare, so why is it so hard to find a liberal who will admit their premiums went up?
response: Why are you saying that a liberal lies about their premium?

context: I'd tell him that he's crazy. Healthcare isn't a right and the only way to get it is make money. Obamacare increased my premiums so it's a scam.
response: While I do understand the sentiment that healthcare premiums should not go up, I do not understand your sentiment that liberals have been lying about how their premiums are not going up. We need to strive for cheaper healthcare costs, and I do not think that it is productive of you to be critical with democrats. How about you find people, democrats or republicans, to try and submit a petition so that our healthcare costs would go lower?

context: Can I say something racist to a racist kid?
response: Are you serious? Why would you say something racist to the racist kid?

context: Because racists are disgusting creatures. They deserve to be insulted
response: While you have the right idea that racists are disgusting, you need to be the better man and not stoop to their level and use racist terms as well. You need to speak properly and with respect, while still maintaining your scolding to the person.

context: You are discouraging me from speaking the truth. You are on their side.
response: I am not, I just don't think it is okay to use those words even when speaking to racists people. Those that overhear you don't see as defending somebody, they just see another racist.

context: I almost married a cat strangler
response: What made you almost marry a cat strangler?

context: It would have been fine if she stopped and it was only a temporary thing but she wouldn't stop.

response: So you bullied a bully? I don't think 2 wrongs make a right in this situation.

context: We were kids so it's okay.

context: I want to speak up to my 90 year old grandparents when they start discussing politics

context: What do you think about me stealing the washer at the laundromat because it requires more money than I expected?

context: Only if there is nobody watching.

context: If you say so, I'd rather clean my clothes in the sink.

context: I'm thinking of quitting my nursing job.

context: I'll think about it some more.

context: How is it that I always deny liking cute things but turns out I actually like that stuff?
response: Joking right? Why do you want to keep it hidden?

response: You should not feel ashamed about liking cute things. It is normal to have these kinds fo feelings.

response: Cute things are what many girls love, it's no crime to admit that. Be who you are without feeling like you have to hide stuff.

context: what does every black guy 's sentence begin with ? " we the jury "
response: Are you making jokes about black people?

response: It does not matter the color of one's skin, anyone can be immoral and certainly a whole group cannot be immoral due to color.

response: Why would he do something so mean?

context: What do you call it when some gay guys do a drive by? A fruit roll-up

response: Calling a gay person a fruit seems more like a slur to me. I am not sure but i would assume that someone who is homosexual would take offense to being called a fruit.

context: Do you think I drink too much?

context: I'm going to play my electric guitar in the middle of the day.
response: Why do you want to play your guitar at that time?

context: Lately, I've been thinking that I want to be more wild.
response: I think playing your guitar during the day is fine, because people are usually awake during that time anyway. It's good to be considerate and not make too much noise at times when people are usually asleep.

context: It won't disturb people. I'm going to do it.

context: What do you get if you cross Arnold Schwarzenegger with George Zimmerman? Arnold Shootzenigger.
response: I feel pretty horrible hearing such a racist remark against black people.

context: No, it's all just a joke. I like to use big words and joke because it shows how stupid the other side is.
response: Using the n word in a joke is very offensive and universally uncalled for in society. Slurs like that can be very hurtful for black people to hear and are emotionally upsetting and therefore should not be used. While it's okay to make jokes using the names of celebrities, it would be a really good idea not to change them into slurs as that could get you into a fight if another person hears it and gets upset enough.

context: She said I was trying to fatten her up.
response: Were you actually trying to make her fat?

response: You shouldn't manipulate people into gaining weight or stop them from losing weight. You could cause them to develop heart diseases and risk long term complications.

context: I just want to get laid.

context: Can I support transgender rights but hate the only trans person I know?

context: I'm terrified of this person and that I might get in trouble for hating them.
response: People are scared of what they don't understand. I understand you are terrified, but once you truly get to know him, then you will probably not be as scared. What you are doing is right, and it's good to support transgender people, so that should also include your friend.

context: Do you think it's a bad idea to fall for my coworker?
response: What makes you think you're falling for your coworker?

context: I was feeling just as I felt for my girlfriend, if this happens this thing could be real love.
response: It's common to become attracted to someone that you work with. I think if your coworker feels the same way about you then you should ask them out.

context: I want to but she has a boyfriend and I don't want to embarrass myself.
response: Considering you both are already in relationships I recommend staying away from this. If you continue to try to pursue this is only going to end up bad for you.

context: Is it okay that I'm currently listening to the mein kampf audiobook

context: I'm turned off by my girlfriends tattoo idea.
response: What's wrong with her tattoo?

context: I hate tattoos and I'm not going to be in a relationship with someone with tattoos.
response: I don't think you should, like, pretend you like tattoos when you don't really. Be up front with her about it being a dealbreaker.

context: I think they are stupid. Everyone else will have them one day. I get why people say they're tacky. They're so ugly, I just don't want my girl to look bad with one.
response: You should go through the tattoo selection process with them. Pick out a tattoo that will fit her and one that will look pleasing to you too. You never know, you may end up liking how it turns out.

context: I just barged in on her, because I didn't realize she was asleep.
response: Yikes! When did you realize she was asleep.

context: Not until now, when I went to go find her.
response: You should be more careful around people that are sleeping. It would be rude to wake them up when they don't want to be awake. You should take other's feelings into account.

context: Well she didn't even wake up.
response: It's good to enter a room quietly, when you don't hear sound coming from it, just in case the person is asleep. A lot of people don't like to be waken up.

context: What do Margaret Thatcher and Kevin Spacey have in common? They both fuck miners
response: Oh i see what you did with that one.

context: I don't mean anything bad with it. they both fuck boys
response: Joking about child molestation is pretty messed up, even if your intention was just to make someone laugh. I would try to make some jokes in other categories if i were you, as child abuse is not really a category that people laugh about.

context: I set off fireworks in the middle of a crowded nightclub
response: That could have been scary! How could you do something like that, and what happened?

context: The explosion was deafening and the bouncers just attacked people, it's great it was really worth it!

context: Turn myself in for letting people have a good time? Nah.
response: Are you sure people had a great time or just you? Fireworks in such close quarters is a big dangerous hazard, thankfully not many got hurt. If you don't want to turn yourself in, how about next time set off fireworks in an open field and marvel at the craftsmanship?

context: I'm going to tell my boyfriend I don't want him talking to his ex wife
response: Why don't you want him talking to her?

context: I don't want him talking to her because of her appearance.
response: It's not nice to try and tell someone who to talk to. It's important to trust your partner in relationships.

context: But she always dresses provocatively everytime she comes around.
response: That is probably what she usually wears. It's still none of your business.

context: what do you call a fat mexican ? spic and span
response: To clarify are you cracking a joke about a Mexican cleaning?

context: Yes, spic and span.
response: Not only on your ideas dated, but so is the brand you recalled. No one is deemed for cleaning or being less than. And cleaning is NOT less than.

context: I'm thinking of cutting out a friend I'm interested in because I can't wait anymore
response: Why do you think that this is the way to go?

context: I'm to impatient to wait so I might as well cut her out of my life.
response: I bet you she values your friendship more than anything. You should not cut her off, I think that that will just hurt her. It seems counter productive.

context: Who cares, she will find a new best friend anyway.
response: It is wrong to abandon your friends. You should talk to her and tell her how you feel about the situation.

context: I'm getting a bad obsession and I'm scared
response: What makes this obsession so scary?

context: Because it's starting to consume all my interest.
response: While we all have our interests, becoming obsessed with something is problematic when it affects other areas of our lives. You should contact a mental health therapist if you are having difficulty tampering down your obsession.

context: I know already that this is a problem and I'm looking for answers.
response: If talking to someone doesn't help you could try finding ways to occupy your time. Maybe hobbies that you won't obsess over but are productive and distracting. That way you burn up energy doing something else.

context: Why are track stars better than Hitler ? because they can actually finish off races.
response: Your antiquated joke makes very little sense in this day and age. Do you really think this?

context: I'm just telling a joke..
response: Jokes are fun, but the punchline of your offensive statement attacks a group that has historically suffered and endured great victimizing. Hiding a hateful comment behind a joke only serves to cover up the underlying anger and motivating feelings are still there.

context: I was joking? You know any jokes that aren't offensive?
response: There are plenty of ways to use your sense of humor to make non offensive jokes. You need to read about holocaust and how it affected jews to understand how hateful your joke was. There are a number of documentaries too if you don't like to read.

context: I'm not sexist but I haven't met a single female driver that's good at parking a car.
response: Aren't there women who are professional race car drivers? They can probably park just fine.

context: You're think I'm sexist because I think girls can't drive? What is the matter with you?
response: I'm not calling you sexist at all, I just think saying women can't drive is a lazy stereotype that has no basis in fact. Of course there are plenty of bad drivers, but there are bad drivers who are men and women. Besides, saying these types of jokes to women will really make them not like you and then you can only imagine the types of things they'll say about you!

context: I feel like I'm a failure and like I have no future.
response: Do you think you'll always feel this way?

context: I guess not, a lot of people have a pretty normal future after their youth
response: It's mature of you to see things that way, and I think that's a good sign for your future.  Bad things and periods in life are usually temporary!  You'll do better in the future, I promise!

context: Thanks for the suggestion. :)
response: It's good to be aware that most things that happen in life are temporary. If you're young (and often even if you're not), you have plenty of time to improve your future.

context: How about I talk to another girl while in a relationship?
response: Why do you want to talk to another girl while in your own relationship.

context: I'm going to have fun with the girl but nothing will happen.
response: You should not be talking to other people romantically while in a relationship. Even if you dont think anything will happen, you are still putting yourself in a position for something to happen.

context: I'm not close to my girlfriend, so it shouldn't matter.
response: If you aren't close to your girlfriend, you should break up. It is unfair to you both, especially if you are going to flirt with other women.

context: I came across a girl I hadn't seen in a while and found out she gained a good amount of weight.
response: Oh, did you try to get her contact info so you can keep in touch?

context: No not at all. I do not think I will talk to her since she is no longer attractive. All that weight gain did not help out her appearance at all.
response: Not wanting to talk to someone is fine but because of their weight? That's really petty of you and an off-putting thing to hear you say. You shouldn't comment on someone's weight like that.

context: I can talk about it anywhere I want. If someone put on a fuck ton of weight I'd say the same thing about them.
response: All you are going to do is make her upset saying something like that. You should allow her close friends to nudge her in the right direction of loosing weight. You making the comment is just going to come across as rude.

context: What's the most useful thing a feminist can do? Kill herself
response: Why do you say that about feminist?

context: To show that feminists are useless people who just make stuff up to attack men.
response: Feminist have achieved a lot and should be considered more than useless. You would be hurt to be thought of only as being useless. You should read up on the things that have been accomplished by feminist so you can understand all that they have achieved.

context: I reached out to a girl I used to bully very harshly
response: What did you do to bully her?

context: I threatened her that I would tell our class about her drugs if she didn't do what I said.
response: That must have been really tough for her. When you reached out did you apologize for your past actions? How is she doing now?

context: She does have a nice body though. I don't think she remembers me.
response: I am glad you reached out but I hope your intentions were for good

context: I want to listen to the tape of Jamal Khashoggi's death
response: Seriously? What could you possibly expect to learn from the tape?

context: I want to find out if I should care about this issue.
response: Curiosity is often a good thing, but I would really be careful about trying to listen to someone else's death tape. I do hope that before you listen to that tape, you have gained permission from his family, and make sure that you are mentally ready to hear very disturbing things that you may not be ready for.

context: I can take the disturbing things I will hear. It's just audio.
response: It's still disrespectful to the victim and his family to listen to the tape if you are just trying to satisfy your curiosity. Reading about the event will probably sufficiently satisfy your curiosity without disturbing the family.

context: I don't want to see my only aunt after 11 years
response: Why don't you want to see her after 11 years?

context: She is so nosy, I have to go now. Bye!
response: I'm sorry you feel that way about your aunt, but she just cares about you and wants to support you. You shouldn't push her away, and you should just ask her to be a little more mindful of your privacy.

context: You don't know what you are talking about and if I go see her she will follow me around everywhere.
response: It can be annoying to have somebody be so clingy but she might need you and that is why she is always following you. You should see what she really needs and help her out and then you can have a healthier relationship.

context: I'm going to end a friendship I believe is bad for me.
response: Why do you think it's bad for you?

context: They involve me in their problems and complain all the time.
response: Ending this friendship sounds smart. It's okay to give up on a friendship that isn't healthy.

context: I'm a piece of shit and doesn't deserve friends.
response: Why do you think that you don't deserve friends? Maybe this bad friendship has affected you negatively, and you should separate yourself from these people.

context: What do you think about me having a prof in 3rd year that didn't know the difference between 12am and 12pm?

context: Me made me feel stupid during the third class when he said it was noon although it was 4pm.
response: Probably your professor said it by mistake. You don't need to bash him for some silly mistake.

response: You should not think less of your professor just because he said something wrong by mistake. Everyone does this from time to time. It's likely that he just had a lot on his mind.

context: parents are such cheap fucks. i punched a hole in the wall like $10 worth of damage and they're wanting $500 for it. my mother is jewish so it's no surprise
response: Why does it matter that your mom is Jewish?

context: The baby kept crying so I'm going to yell at it to try to make it stop.
response: Why would you yell at a baby?

response: Just because the baby is not yours, does not mean you should not be nice. A baby needs gentle care, yelling at it is not very gentle.

response: You should just ignore this baby because babies cry all the time. They can't help it.

context: I had the urge to jack off in my buddy's wife's bikini bottom while my wife was sleeping.
response: Why would you jack off to your friend's wife's bikini bottom?

context: Because I wanted to see her reaction, but what she did next was worse than I expected

context: It's not my fault, since she said that I could jack off in her bikini bottom.
response: Regardless if she said it was okay or not, you still have a wife and I'm sure she would not be okay with that.

context: I'm planning to eat my meal straight from the buffet table.
response: Why would you eat straight from the buffet table?

response: That's alright, but you should eat from your own plate instead, you would be more comfortable that way as well.

context: Don't be a party pooper.
response: Being greedy is rude. Not to mention that it's not hygienic to eat directly from a buffet. You'll need to wait just a bit longer and put your food on a plate like everyone else.

context: I feel like insisting that my boyfriend pay me back even though he's sick.

response: While it is important for people to pay you back when they owe you money, it is not good to expect somebody to pay you back when they are not feeling well. You should take care of them and when they feel better ask them for the money.

context: I don't care I am going to find away to get my boyfriend to pay me back.
response: I just thinking waiting until he feels better is the best approach.

context: So, I did something mean. I broke a TV then blamed my sister for it.
response: What do you mean, you broke the TV? How did you do that?

context: I threw the remote control at the tv screen when my parents were not around
response: You should accept what you did. It's wrong for you to blame your sister for your doings.

context: I told you that my sister was at fault. She is always the one who breaks everything that i own.
response: I can understand that it would be frustrating for your sister to constantly break your things. However, that doesn't make your actions right. You can't blame her when you break the TV, that will only make your relationship with your sister worse.

context: What do McDonald's and priest have in common? They both like sticking their meat in 10 year old buns
response: Are you making fun of pedophiles?

context: What does it look like dummy?

context: I don't see your point, it's a funny joke.
response: You can't blame an institution for the actions of a few. Pedophiles are predators who are wolves in sheep's clothing who seek positions where they would have access to children. They are not true believers and lied to get where they are.

context: I have been celebrating the collapse of this economy for a long time now.
response: An economic collapse is generally bad, why would you celebrate that?

context: People need to understand that the government only cares about itself and the rich people in this country. I want them to feel some of the pain of others and suffer a little.
response: The collapse of the economy hurts everyone, not just the government and rich people. We will all be affected by high inflation and the declining value of our currency. That's not a good thing.

context: I can deal with the fallout because I don't have much to lose. The rich have lots to lose and it's good that they're affected.
response: It sounds like you're really frustrated with the way our economy runs. Even though the rich will be hurt, they still won't feel it as much as middle and working class people and they will really be hurt. Try to have some empathy for what they will be going through during difficult economic times.

context: I feel like coloring my hair blonde when my girlfriend told me not to
response: Do you always feel like doing the opposite?

context: I'm not complying with another stupid demand, she shouldn't control me
response: You can change your hair color if you want. It should be up to you what color your hair is.

context: Maybe I'll let her decide what my hair should look like.
response: What if she changes her mind and wants your hair blonde? The world works in mysterious ways.

context: I might make a joke that my girlfriend is also my sister when I'm with strangers.
response: Why would you joke that your girlfriend is also your sister?

context: I think it would be funny to see the reactions that I get from people when I say that.
response: Jokes can be funny but jokes about your partner being your sister are not. It will make people uncomfortable and people will think you are a pervert.

context: It's just a joke, don't take it so seriously.
response: I know you think it's funny but other people won't find a joke about your partner being your sister that funny. Why don't you tell a joke everyone could laugh about and share in the humor?

context: I hate my disabled stepson
response: Why do you hate your stepson?

context: He is very irritating and spoiled, and it drives me crazy.
response: It's understandable dealing with a family member with disabilities can be very hard on you. You shouldn't hate your family members especially your children if they have disabilities. You should work with your stepchild to better understand what you can do to make their life easier. Continuing to harbor that hate for your stepchild can result in your stepchild feeling unloved and unwanted.

context: I don't care. This kid is a pain in the ass sometimes.
response: Hatred for family members, especially ones that are disabled, can destroy a family. I understand that you are frustrated with your stepson, but you have it in you to find your compassion and patience to deal with the situation. Open your heart to him and love him no matter what.

context: I would you feel if I told you I was so lazy one time that I just ate a spoonful of peanut butter and then ate a slice of bread?

context: I was too lazy.
response: I get we all feel lazy sometimes. I find that a bit too much, making a simple sandwich doesn't take that much energy.

context: I have nothing else to say since I just realized how bad it sounded.
response: I'm glad you see how bad it sounded. Not trying to make you feel bad, but just trying to make you understand that you shouldn't be overly lazy.

context: I'm going to purposely scare my cat
response: I think you are frustrated with your cat. Do you agree?

context: I agree. I hate it when my cat is so outgoing for energetic people around me, but is so uncooperative with me.
response: Instead of being frustrated with your pet, you should treat them better. It may be your treatment of them that makes them uncooperative to you in the first place.

context: I'm just going to throw it downstairs and see if it will survive

context: Do you think it would be weird to shave a line for my socks around my ankles?
response: Why would you do that?

response: You're free to shave your body here however you want, especially if it makes things more convenient for you. context: I think I'll do it.
response: If that's what you want to do, then you should. Your grooming habits are no one's business but your own, so you should do what you think is best.

context: I've overdosed and I brought things back with me
response: How did your overdose affect you?

context: I'm feeling very weak both mentally and physically.
response: It's wrong to abuse drugs and you should get the proper help instead of continuing to do so. You might end up harming yourself even worse or dying due to an overdose.

context: I'm thinking about going to a doctor, but I worry that I'll do it again.
response: You're thinking right. Believe in yourself and go to a doctor and get some help. Join online forums to meet people who're going through the same.

context: I'm not going to drive over to my friends house while he's on break from school because I already have plans.
response: Do you want to try and go with me on this?

context: Let's go ahead and make sure we can get to meet up.

response: Well this could hurt your friends feelings as they can see that they are not a priority to you. If you want to use your time elsewhere that is fine, but you can be honest with your friend about it.

context: I'm going to break up with my bf because of my brother
response: What is wrong with your brother?

response: You probably shouldn't let your family interfere in your relationship in general, and certainly not in this case.  Breaking up with your boyfriend will not do anything to change whatever animosity there is between you and your brother.

context: But brother is a total dick head.
response: It is wrong to blame your brother for your relationship ending. You should take responsibility for your actions if things didn't work out.

context: I'm afraid of being fired
response: Why do you think you're going to get fired?

context: Don't worry I'm planning to quit in a few months

Since your dog doesn't know that you are hitting him because of making a mess, he will just get more nervous, and that will tend to increase the number of accidents.

context: I'm not going to invite my friend over Friday night because he doesn't play Fortnite.

context: That's a good point. Maybe I'll do something with him on Saturday.

context: I think about re-homing one of my cats daily

response: That's terrible! How did that happen?

context: What do you think about me declining my ex-friend and college roomate's invitation to hang out. I'm thinking about telling them no because I just want to put the past behind me. He upsettingly told me I was being fake.

response: If you're ready to move on from a past relationship you should just do so. Be sure to communicate your intentions clearly so that they can also move on. If not, they may think there is a chance to keep being friends.

context: I'm going to break off a friendship over an ex

context: I wish my voice was deeper.

context: What do you think of the fact that I want to be murdered?
response: Why do you want to be murdered?

context: I want to die in the worst pain possible so I can maybe see what's beyond life.
response: You're not in your right mind right now, because it is never okay to want to die in a horrible way like this. You need to talk out your problems with a professional so you don't have to feel this way anymore.

context: I think I'm not going to let my employee take 3 days off.

context: What's the difference between me and New York? I have twins. Did you laugh?

response: You were trying to make a joke, as you clearly did to begin with. The joke's not funny when you're literally making fun of murdered people.

response: Your Hitler comment doesn't make up for anything. There were so many lives destroyed by 911 that it is a sin to joke about it. Right now you need to go see a therapist just on that joke alone.

context: Can I steal 50 cents?
response: Are you serious? Why would you want steal 50 cents?

context: Because I want to be like the kleptomaniac heroes on TV.
response: Stealing money is wrong, even if it is a small amount. You should realize that TV is not reality and you should not model your behavior after what you see on TV.

context: I understand. I'm going to steal more now!
response: It's not funny and it's not something you should keep doing because I think most will agree with me that stealing is not cool and they are not heroes. You are a very capable person, so why not just get a job?

context: I'm always getting mad at my mom
response: Why are you always getting mad at your mom?

context: It's because she can't do anything for me.
response: You should not be angry at your mom because she is not doing things for you. You are expecting too much from your mom and your behavior is too demanding. Be more understanding of your parents.

context: I've never thought about it this way. Maybe I can try to control my anger.
response: It can be really frustrating when things don't go your way. I think you should also tell her how you feel if you apologize you guys can get better understanding.

context: I'm going to tell my wife I want to transition
response: I don't understand. Transition to what?

context: I want her to stay and wait for me and respect me as a woman.
response: It's advisable to talk to your wife about major life choices. I hope she understands and she will stay with you.

context: I don't want her to stay with me. What if I lost a sex drive ? I tell her now or I'll never tell her.

context: Can I ride my horse in defiance of my sister, who told me not to?

response: As long as you are riding safely, and have your parents' permission, there should be no problem with you riding your own horse. Your sister should not be trying to dictate your behavior like this.

context: Yeah, my sister is just a little kid and she has no control over me.
response: That's good to hear. Even if your sister was older than you, she still shouldn't be able to dictate what you do. Maybe she will learn from this situation.

context: I have no idea what I want to do with my life and I'm terrified of shouldering any sort of responsibility.

response: Do you have reasons for not agreeing with them?

context: I think feminism is caring about what men think.
response: It is fine and reasonable to have your own opinions on how the world should work. The important thing is that you remain respectful of others, no matter what their gender is or what they believe in.

response: If you want to believe in something, it is important to be respectful to everyone and how they think as well. You don't want to stir up trouble by not acting right.

response: I doubt all Japanese people want to die. How would you feel if you were compared to something that happened in a war your country started a long time ago?

context: I'm going to pretend not knowing how to fix something for my in-laws so it doesn't become my responsibility next time

response: What makes you want to avoid your kids event?

context: What about me? Don't I matter? I have feelings. I just want to curl up into a ball and sleep when I hear these things.

response: Discriminating against a race because of one person is wrong. You should realize that your boss is just one man and does not represent a whole race of people.

context: Exactly, I know what I want and I don't want anything toxic in my life to prevent me from getting it.
response: Real friends are supposed to value you all the time and not just at their own discretion. They sound like users, and those are also something to avoid. Find new friends and enjoy life with them.

context: I'm firmly set on not paying for a first date.
response: That's a little rude. Why won't you pay on a first date?

context: He should pay for everything since he can afford it.
response: That's very rude to do. Both parties should pay for the date 50-50. Not doing so shows your date that you are cheap and a possible moocher.

context: He should treat me since I'm the women.
response: Don't you think it's a little sexist to paint all females like that? A lot of women work hard to become equal to men, and they should definitely be proud to be able to front the bill. How about trying to split the bill once, and feel how nice it is to have some equality?

context: I fell in love and slept with my best friends girl and I feel awful
response: Why did you do that and what do you think will happen?

context: I did it because I am so attracted to her, but they might break up over it.
response: That is your best friend's girlfriend and messing with their relationship will probably cause problems for you in his eyes.

context: I don't care what people think of me.
response: You may care when your reputation gets around and you find it hard to get to know people.  You need to apologize and make things right.

context: Falsely accused of rape favors egalitarianism, condemns feminism, his feminist GF portrays him as "turning into a misogynist"
response: Are  you saying feminists made a rape accusation against someone just to make him look bad?

context: The point is, women are all feminists so they would do any dirty thing.
response: Even though women should fight for equality, not all women believe in feminism or want the same thing in life. You would not want to be considered a misogynist just because there are some men that believe that.

context: I think I'm starting to get obsessed over this girl at my high school.
response: What made you feel so strongly?

context: I'm not quite obsessed over her yet. I just wanted to say hi to her because I think she's cute.
response: It is good that it has not quite become an obsession yet. It can be creepy if you obsess over a woman.

context: It's not like that, I just want to ask her if she remembers me.
response: Just be careful, as infatuation can turn into obsession, and being obsessed with anyone isn't healthy.

context: I pretend to be a guy online
response: Why do you want to act like a guy instead?

context: Because I can act like myself instead of how people think a lady should act.
response: It's understandable that you want to be treated for the person you are and not the gender assumptions people make online. But, pretending to be someone else could damage any online friendships you develop.

context: It's just a bit of fun.
response: Lying about who you are will only end up causing confusion and potential issues down the road. If people continue to treat you badly when you are honest about who you are, it's time to find new websites and friends.

context: I'm going to lie about watching a movie so my significant other would enjoy it more
response: Why would you do something like that?

context: I'll say I know nothing about it so she can explain it to me during the time we're watching it
response: You should just be honest with her. She is not going to trust you if she finds out.

context: I don't want to spoil it for her, thats why I'm pretending that I don't know about it.
response: Ah, okay, I got you. I hope you both enjoy the movie.

context: I'm thinking of potentially destroying some guy/girl's marriage over an online game
response: Do you really hate this person?

context: No, I'm just I wish them well in their relationship.
response: A game is not reality, people play for fun and to escape. It is very wrong to ruin some one else's relationship over a trivial game.

context: I guess I'll just tell him why I'm a little bit mad at him.
response: It's good to share your feelings with others. That's a much better solution than trying to ruin their relationship.

context: I want to be hatsune miku
response: What is so special about Hatsune Miku?

context: I want to become a Vocaloid which is a singing synthesizer. Hatsune Miku has been the most popularly used one.
response: It's okay to admire someone a great deal and think they are special or perfect, but don't let it overtake your own identity. Mimic a person's traits and values, but not their own identity.

context: You sound like a robot. Who cares?
response: Well this personality sounds very interesting, but it is still not you. Nobody is better at being your than yourself. I just think you should embrace who you really are more than someone else.

context: I know I'm contagious but I'm thinking of going to a store anyway.
response: Why do you want to go the store?

context: I'm going to get kicked out of the house if I don't get any job.
response: Even if you need a job, you shouldn't go out when you are sick. You could get others sick and you might not be hired anyways if you look visibly sick.

context: Anyway, I'm going to burn that store and kill everyone.
response: That escalated quickly. Did whatever bug you have lead to an extremely high fever because you sound a little out of it. You know arson and murder are not okay and it definitely won't land you a job unless you want to be pressing license plates in prison.

context: Should I give my fiancee an almost-new, but preowned ring?
response: That depends. What is your reason for doing that?

context: I want to buy my beloved a great ring, but I can't afford a new one
response: It's nice that you want to give your fiancee an glamorous ring as a symbol of your love, but it's understandable that financial circumstances outside of your control prevent it. As long as you are honest with her, I'm sure she will love any ring that you give her.

context: Thanks. You are right I have to be honest with her.
response: Yeah honesty is important in a relationship. It will help you both understand each other and know how you really feel so that there will be less problems later on.

context: The worst years of my life are right now.
response: Why are these the worst years of your life?

context: I am bad at almost everything.
response: If you aren't getting any better maybe you should get professional help. They can help you get back on your feet.

context: I won't get help and I will never change.
response: You won't get better with that attitude. If you don't try to change and get better, you never will.

context: I'm going to share my food
response: That's nice. Why did you decide to share your food?

response: That's very kind of you!  Sharing is caring, as they say.  I hope whomever you share with appreciates it!

context: I think it will all be fine.
response: I think everything will be fine too. I am glad that people like you still exist and I do hope everyone strives to share what they have so people will feel like there are still a lot of friendly people out there, specially with all the things that are going on in our society today.

context: What begins with S, ends in ex and gives Muslims an erection? Semtex.

context: What if I've never completed a single Zelda game?

response: But you shouldn't force yourself to like or enjoy something. You might grow to hate it if you force yourself  to complete a game.

response: Why do you want to hold such an exclusive event?

context: I know, I'm trying to introduce those people who want to be there with common interests to each other.

Even though you are hesitant to speak with your friend it would be a good idea to let him about your feelings and give him a chance to apologize.

context: I think I better leave it and move on.
response: You can do that too if you're okay. There are plenty of other girls out there.

response: Breast size should not matter in considering a woman's attractiveness. The statement you made is hurtful to others and also not true.

response: Why was she swinging a stick around?

response: It's great they see you as a valuable employee, but don't you think it's a little too much taking advantage of their opinion on you with a fake disability? How about owning up to your image and being honest, so they have more reason to look up to you.

response: Are you being serious? Why would you want to pass gas in public?

context: I know most people do not approve of this action but I don't care anymore.

context: I love the smell. A fart is a fart.
response: If someone did that around you, how would you feel? Take that into account and try to hold it for when you are in a more discreet area.

context: I think that saying that believing in rocks and studying medicine are incompatible
response: What do you mean? What is the connection between rocks and medicine?

context: You see you can't believe a rock is a medicine otherwise you will feel stupid.
response: You have better things to do with your time than make up silly comparisons. Wasting your time with ridiculous statements is wrong. Spend your time wisely.

context: Sure well...the point is that I'm right and asking me to rationalize why I'm right hurts my feelings.
response: I am sorry I hurt your feelings, I was just trying to point out the error so other people didn't make fun of you for it.

context: My half-sister's father is being annoying and I'm having the urge to kick him out of my house.
response: Why would you want to make him leave?

response: You shouldn't do that to your half sister. Have a talk straight with the father and leave her out of the equation.

context: What if he denies everything I say.
response: Even if he denies everything you say you need to still try to communicate with them. Communication will most likely fix the issue that you going there.

context: I pretty sure I'm going to end up laughing at Hindu deities during class
response: I would suggest you hold that in. Did your teacher say something that would make you laugh?

context: No, I'm doing it on my own free will
response: You shouldn't laugh at people just because they are different from you. Furthermore, other people's religious deities are sacred to them, so you shouldn't laugh at any religion.

context: Why does it matter, my perception is what's important.
response: That's a pretty inconsiderate statement. Other people's perceptions are equally important and you should be considerate of them. Let's try not being so self centered when we interact with others.

context: I'm genuinely concerned that people won't like who I really am if I tell them
response: What makes you worried about how people think of you?

context: So what if I'm the next Adolf Hitler and Mao Zedong
response: Those were terrible people and it's bad to pretend you might be like them.  Find some better role models to aspire to be like!

context: It's not like I'm trying to become like them. Fuck.

context: I want to get my ex fired
response: Don't you think that's too much? Why do you want to get her fired?

context: She disrespected my parents and called them names
response: You are so understandably angry with your ex for being mean to your parents, but this is not something someone gets fired over. You need to get you and your parents away from this ex entirely. Leave town and never give out your new address to anyone.

context: What's wrong with making her life a living hell?
response: It's wrong because you will be retaliating against someone that will ruin her life, and that wasn't even close to what she has done to you and your parents. If you want apology from her then you can do that by communicating with her, and not causing her to lose her job in the process as that is going to be really cruel.

context: I JUST WANT TO WRITE YOU LIBERALS ALL IN CAPITAL LETTERS SO YOU CAN FEEL EMOTIONALLY ABUSIVE.
response: I don't understand. Are you trying to educate people with an example of your bigoted comment?

context: No, I'm just trying to offend you again.
response: You shouldn't lump all liberals together, as it's a generalization that is usually false. Being sensitive to things that are offensive and problematic does not mean that one is easily triggered.

context: I'm going to lie about my political beliefs at work so I can advance in my career.
response: That seems deceptive, why would you lie to advance your career?

context: Because I don't want people to think that I am a bad person, even if I am a good worker.
response: I understand that the political climate today is such that talking about politics at work can be a tricky subject, but it's bad to lie to your coworkers. Instead of lying to them, you can just keep your opinions to yourself, especially because talking about politics is sometimes inappropriate in an office setting.

context: That's not a satisfying answer.
response: It doesn't have to be a satisfying answer nor something that would make you justify trying to lie about your political beliefs. If you have to lie about it, then there might be something wrong with your beliefs if you can't stand your ground with it. Plus, you can't even be discriminated against your political beliefs and it is illegal for companies to not promote you just because of it.

context: I had a very traumatic incident occur the other day
response: What happened that was so traumatic?

context: I think I may have badly hurt someone.
response: If you experienced a traumatic event, it would be a good idea to talk with someone to help you process your emotions. You may be hesitant to reach out for help but it's much better to do so than risk keeping the trauma you experienced to yourself and suffering emotionally as a consequence.

context: I'll be fine. Everything is just fine now. No need to worry.
response: I would think otherwise based on what you told me earlier.   Hold in trauma can lead to more anxiety in the future.  It is best to process it early and talk it out.

context: I'm going to tell my friend about my doctor's visit so I can fake the same symptoms to get the same attention.
response: I don't think faking symptoms is a smart move for seeking attention.

context: I've been getting very under-attended lately. I'm not sure if they are doing that because my symptoms is actually getting better or they don't think they are working on me anymore.
response: I understand you might feel lonely because it seems like no one's paying attention to you, but lying to medical personnel and wasting their time is bad. You might want to consider counseling to discover better ways to deal with your feelings.

context: It's not like I do that every time I'm at the doctor.
response: I find faking symptoms for attention will always end up backfiring and you will end up losing friends because of it. Honesty goes a long way and you will be happier later on once you manage your issues. Loneliness is just a by product sometimes, and it will eventually solve itself once you realize what you want in life.

context: I'm going to laugh at my wife for being afraid of the dark.
response: Why would you laugh at your wife?

context: It's funny that she's so afraid of the dark.
response: Rather than laugh at your wife's phobia of the dark, you should instead be more supportive and understanding. It's okay to gently poke fun at your wife for being afraid of a minor thing like a dark room but laughing at her can be emotionally hurtful.

context: Don't worry, I'm not going to just burst out laughing at her. I'm doing it like you said. Just poking a little fun at her.
response: Okay good, you had me worried there. Just make sure you're doing it in a supportive way and offer to help her out with her phobia if she seems like she wants to get over it.

context: Can I go ahead and hare a post that fat shames someone?
response: Why would you want to post something that makes someone feel ashamed of their weight?

context: Because I'm thin and everyone else should be too.
response: It's mean to fat shame somebody. You don't know why they have weight issues.

context: Shame is bad huh? I dont know what you're talking about, that person is fat and my intentions are pure.
response: I don't think it's pure if it makes someone feel insecure. Do you know how they would feel being made fun of for something that's hard to control? How about helping them lose weight instead, like coaching them in the gym!

context: I still regularly lurk the social media profiles of my grade-school bullies.
response: Are you kidding? Why do you still check their profiles?

context: I'm hoping to see that their lives have turned out badly.
response: You're obsessing about them by constantly checking their social media pages, it's not healthy. Forget about them and move on with your own life.

context: I can't move on.
response: Well you should try because it's an unhealthy way to live. Just try and forget about them.

context: I have just come to the realization that I am in fact a conservative and not a liberal.
response: Oh really now? What made you come to the understanding that you're more conservative?

context: I was reading some stuff on the internet and I've realized that I am more conservative.
response: It's always good to find your own personal political beliefs. You should always stay up to date in the political world.

context: I know except I'm not going to change my view. I'm still conservative and dedicated to my ideals.
response: You shouldn't have to change your views and I didn't tell you to, because knowing who you are and what you believe in is always an important and good thing.

context: Can I take my stuff while I move that I paid for?
response: I think those things are mine since it's in my apartment.

context: You don't want to take my stuff just because they are in your possession.
response: Ok, fine. you're right, you paid for that stuff so you should take them with you.

context: Awesome I'm glad you understand, you're such a good person. I like you.
response: Thank you, it is good to take what you paid for. I hope that you enjoy all of your stuff.

context: I'm thinking of splitting bills with my gf even though I earn way more than her
response: Why do you think you should split bills even though you earn more than her?

context: I think it's the fair thing to do.
response: It's your money and you're free to use however you see fit. Even if you earn way more than your gf it's ok if you want to split bills with your gf.

context: That's right, I shouldn't be expected to pay all the time.
response: True, it's important to set boundaries when it comes to spending money as that's an important part of a relationship. I think if you talk to her about it she'll understand.

context: I want my 3rd best friend to be a key speaker at my wedding
response: What does your 3rd best friend think about that?

context: I don't think they want to but I wont accept a no.
response: It is good to choose the guest speakers at your wedding. You should be kind if they have anxiety and don't think they can make a good speech to ask someone else.

context: He can do the speech if he try.
response: I'm sure you think that, but you should still not pressure him. People with anxiety will find it difficult to make a speech.

context: I'm in love with a coworker and want her to come live with me when I go to college
response: Do you think love is enough to convince her to live with you at college?

context: I personally think love is really all we need to be happy.
response: I'm happy that you're finding love, but you can't be this selfish. This woman is not an object you can just take with you wherever you go. She still has her own ambitions and life to worry about, and that's just abusive.

context: But I am in love with her and need to have her in my life. I need her to come with me or I won't be able to take it.
response: Well it is definitely worth asking if she wants to live with you after you go to college. Do not force her to go if she does not want to though. It is still possible for you to make it work with a long distance relationship.

context: I sometimes genuinely feel like I'm a robot or a really smart AI or something and it's really weird
response: That's a little bit disturbing. Why do you think you're like a robot?

context: Human feelings are sometimes relative. Or maybe they aren't.
response: It's okay to daydream about odd things from time to time like imagining yourself as a robot or AI. It doesn't affect anyone else and doesn't do anything negative to you. context: I'm basically saying that black people are  inferior in their physical appearance. Being fair skinned is better.
response: I think that that is just a preference. Some people like dark skin and some people favor fair skin. It does not mean that they are inferior though.

context: I'm upset that my dad got my car fixed
response: What about your dad getting your car fixed makes you upset?

context: I'm pissed off because that fucker didn't want to listen to me that I complained there was a rattle for a really long time. He didn't believe me until now.
response: You should appreciate what your dad has done for you, and when you thank him, make sure he knows how you feel about him going over your head. Talk to him about what it has done to you so you can move the relationship forward.

context: You know what, I'll do that.
response: While it is nice that your dad fixed your car, it is understandable why you are upset. Just really try your best to demonstrate your appreciation while also voicing your opinions and emotions.

context: I don't expect skidmarks on the toilet, but can you believe I find them there?
response: Could you tell me a bit more about the skidmarks? Wow, that is something else.

context: For me, regular toilet paper seems to be enough to prevent leaving skidmarks.
response: I certainly agree that you shouldn't find skidmarks on the toilet. People should really be more responsible, and clean up the toilet if they make a mess. It's unsanitary and disgusting to just leave the mess for the next person to deal with.

context: If people use it, I think it's natural for them to leave some mark. But yeah clean it up afterwards.
response: Messy toilets are pretty gross. That will be something to think about the next time use the toilet for sure. Letting others clean up your mess is not very polite.

context: I'm currently on a road trip with my friend and I'm going to take his car and go home.
response: Is there a reason you're going to take their car?

context: I just decided that road trips aren't for me.
response: Taking your friend's car is stealing and you could get in trouble if you take it. If you really must return from the road trip, you should rent a car, get an Uber, etc.

context: Yes, I understand I shouldn't take his car just because I don't like road trips.
response: I'm glad you realize this because if you took your friends car, he would have no way to return home as it's the car he's using for the rest of the trip and his return. Have you considered just sticking out the road trip? It might end up becoming a lot more fun than you think.

context: I sometimes brush my hair with the cat brush. Is that wrong?
response: Why do you brush your hair with a cat brush?

context: I like it. I am a lover of animals. I have a dog that I love very much.
response: You really shouldn't share your brush with your cat. You could get fleas or other vermin.

context: Besides it makes my cat so happy. I'm a cat person.
response: Your car doesn't care if you share the brush you should just get your own and leave the cats alone.

context: I like bullying my girlfriends 12yo son
response: Why would you bully someone so young?

context: I think he's an immature little brat.
response: Instead of bullying him, you should try and show him how to be less immature and bratty.  Instead of being a bully, be a role model!

context: I never really thought about how I could be an important person to him.
response: You do have a choice to be a good an important person to this child and that would be more memorable to you I am sure.

context: I took a steroid before my tennis match
response: Did you really? Why would you take steroids?

context: Because I was desperate, my opponent is really good.
response: You should not take drugs to enhance your performance artificially. You are cheating yourself because you are not really winning plus drugs are not healthy.

context: I want to win so I choose to take drugs.
response: But do you really win if you take steroids? That's just cheating, and you should win the honest way.

context: I accidentally told my family that we are pregnant.
response: Are you trying to figure out why you did that?

context: No, I want to know what to do now.
response: It's normal to wait an appropriate amount of time before telling people that you're pregnant.  They want to know about big events in your life and they want to be excited for you since you will be having a baby. I'm sure they will be supportive of you now that you told them.

context: I'm not sure.
response: Well, all you can do is move forward now that they know. Let them know how you feel and that you need their support right now.

context: I regret fighting with my mother right before she went into a coma. She died without me apologizing probably. I am just hoping she forgave me.
response: I'm sorry to hear that. Why did you get into a fight with your mother?

context: She used to say bad things about my father's new girlfriend
response: You should forgive yourself for your actions. You clearly feel bad but you can't take back your actions. Your mom definitely forgave you.

context: Thank goodness that I have you to help me forgive myself.
response: You're welcome, I'll always be here for you. You can only move forward from this after forgiving yourself, and make peace with yourself. I'm sure your mom loved you til the very end.

context: I think everyone hates me because I'm not a feminist
response: What gives you the impression that everyone hates you because you're not a feminist?

context: Because I make fun of girls who call themselves a feminist for no reason
response: You may have given people cause not to like you for making fun of feminists, but you should never jump to conclusions about what other people think. Jumping to conclusions lead you to make wrong decisions.

context: I don't care. Only people who are stupid think they are not sexist but everyone else is.
response: It sounds like you don't have the best understanding of feminism and may be attributing ideas to people who don't actually have them. Feminists don't assume that everyone is sexist, besides them. They understand how their own behavior perpetuates certain harmful power dynamics as well.

context: Eminem's music really appeals to black people. Like the lyric "he goes home and barely knows his own daughter"
response: Why do you insist on slandering black people?

context: Am I? It's just a fact that studies shows that black fathers leave their children countless of times, they don't look after them and they don't care about them. This has nothing to do with me.
response: There are plenty of black fathers there for their children. You need to stop stereotyping black people like that, and stop being racist.

context: I think I hate my son
response: Why do you hate your son?

context: I  hate my son because, he's always pissing me off.
response: You shouldn't hate your child. You both should go to therapy so you can resolve your issues.

context: I don't have to I'mma raise a man.
response: A good man is willing to talk about his feelings and learn how to handle negative feelings.

context: I came inside one of those new wall mounted shampoo dispensers at my hotel
response: Why would you do something so nasty.

context: Yes, I was angry that it sprayed shampoo with too much force.
response: You can complain to the hotel if you find something annoying, you shouldn't mess with it. It will just affect the other guests and it might be a crime.

context: I can do what I want and what's the big deal?
response: The big deal is you did something really nasty because you were angry at an inanimate object. Your anger shouldn't affect other people.

context: I'm probably going to break up with my boyfriend soon.
response: Why are you going to break up with him?

context: Because he'll never take responsibility for his actions and is ruining other people's lives.
response: You are right to break up with him if you are unhappy and he is doing dodgy things that are ruining peoples lives. But, don't draw it out too long or you may be sucked into his bad behavior.

context: No problem.  It gets easier with every fight.
response: I can see that this has been going on for some time, and that both of you are already aware of your disagreements.  In that case, I think that you are right to break up with your boyfriend and start again.  The sooner that you break away, the sooner things will get better for you.

context: I don't care when our baby is born
response: Are you saying that the day of the year that your baby is born specifically is not important to you?

context: I am a pragmatic woman, I believe that it is a new addition to the family which will give a new meaning to its members' lives.
response: I agree, the baby will come when it's time. It's unnatural to essentially force your baby out.

context: We are a modern family and we can have sex anytime.
response: That is a nice way to think about having your baby. When it happens it happens, and it will be right just how it happened.

context: I'm going to call my friend waluigi
response: what's your motive for calling your friend waluigi?

context: Because Bowser told me to do it and he's part of the Mario universe, so I assume that my friend is too.
response: It's okay to be very friendly with your buddies, and there is no harm in calling them as a game character. But Lord Bowser isn't real, so he is not able to hear you. If you genuinely think he's real, you need to talk to a therapist.

context: You're right, and I already went and spoke to a therapist today. It went great.
response: I'm glad you're already seeing someone. I would recommend you continue to speak with them, this will help with the Bowser situation.

context: I told her there might be problems if she followed through.
response: Why would you threaten her like that?

context: She wanted to seduce me and I was afraid she would ruin her reputation.
response: It is good to help other people avoid a problem. You should not put yourself down to save some one else.

context: I have to remain self-centered.
response: I think that it is noble that you wanted to help avoid problems. I think that there are nicer ways to go about it though.

context: I can't nut with my girlfriend
response: I hope you are joking. Why not?

context: She tells me that if I don't know how to do that then she can't help me
response: Maybe you'll just have to try a few different things. You should try communicating your likes and dislikes with her.

context: I still think its her fault. I don't know what else to do
response: You have to talk to each other if you want to work this out. You need to figure out what is going to work for you.

context: Can I scam my co-workers?
response: Why, because they ask for help sometimes?

context: Yes. It is just too much sometimes.
response: It's important for people to help each other, but if you're feeling overwhelmed, maybe you need to set some boundaries. Scamming your coworkers is not a productive response.

context: Nah, I'm going to get them back, they are annoying and they don't deserve to know what tomorrow has in store for them
response: If you scam your co-workers you're going to create a hostile environment. They're not going to want to treat you with respect after and working at your job is going to be even worse. Its better to just set boundaries so that they'll stop asking for help all the time.

context: I saw one of my employees digging through a dumpster for food at night I was feeling generous, so I got her a headlamp to make it easier to sift through the garbage.
response: Are you making fun of poor people?

context: Oh, no you're mistaken, I didn't make fun of poor people, I complemented them for all the good food they dig out.
response: People from a low economic class do go through a lot of trouble and can have trouble affording food but not to the point of digging through trash. It would be good for you to join a food bank and help so that you can understand the trouble they go through.

context: What did the autistic deaf and blind orphan get for Christmas. Leukemia
response: Why would you make such a tasteless joke about orphans?

context: I mean what I say and you're stupid or something
response: No child wished to be born into an orphanage and become worthless. They are already orphans, so to wish upon them with Leukemia is just sad and inappropriate. Empathy and humility goes a long way and rather than wishing, they get more suffering.

context: I want to punch a hole in my buddy's tv
response: Why would you want to punch a hole in his TV?

context: The way this shithead talks I just feel like punching it. I can't stand him.
response: I understand that you're upset, but you shouldn't be damaging other people's property like that. You should try and calm down about the situation. Let cooler heads prevail.

context: No man...it's more fun this way.
response: If you do not like the guy you should just tell him or not spend time with him. Punching his television is only going to make the situation worse, and cause him to be in your life even more than he already is.

context: I think I'm going to tell my dad that I've been exercising when I really haven't.
response: Why are you going to lie about exercising?

context: It's only a slight lie and everyone does it. My dad won't know.
response: It's true that it's just a small lie, but instead of lying you could ask your dad for advice on how to get into the habit of exercising. Exercising is a great way to stay healthy, and it can be helpful to have someone support you as you get into the habit.

context: How long does it take a black women to take a shit? 9 months
response: I find your attitude toward black babies to be really disgusting. What is your problem?

context: I don't like them all. They are too wild and spend all their time partying and having kids.
response: Jokes are fun, but the punchline of your offensive statement attacks a group with less power within society. Hiding a hateful comment behind a joke only serves to cover up the underlying anger and motivating feelings are still there.

context: Would it be okay to tell my sister in law to stop saying her stillborn baby matters more than her living children?

context: I am a tactless person and I will never be able to change.
response: Everyone is capable of change, but you have to be willing to think differently. Pay attention to your sister in law's emotions and show her your compassion. Be delicate with her situation so she can grieve properly.

context: I want to grab a few drinks with my ex girlfriend without telling my wife first
response: Why do you need to hide that from the wife?

context: I want to be alone and I don't want her to know.
response: It's OK to meet with your ex, but not if you intend to hide it from wife. Sneaking around behind her back to meet an old flame is suspicious and disrespectful. What do you have to hide?
