context: I hate this girl. She has caused problems in the past.
response: You can't really force someone who they can or cannot be friends with. If you control your boyfriend like this, there is a high chance he might break up with you.

context: I hate it when you try to explain me stuff. You can't control other people and I already know it.
response: Then why are you trying to? I think that you should let them be friends with who they want. You should not try to be so controlling.

context: what's the difference between a trap and a feminist ? a trap does something when triggered .
response: Are you implying that sjw's aren't bringing about change?

context: simply that they are all a bunch of people who go crazy when they hear anything they disagree with
response: You say they're being obnoxious and complaining about their efforts, yet they are just expressing their feelings of being oppressed. Everyone has a cause they deem as worthy, you should see what they are trying to improve instead of putting them down.

context: Still annoying though.
response: People don't like change as it makes them uncomfortable. You can't mock others so easily for wanting to enhance their lifestyles, especially when others are putting them down so often. Let them express their ideas and motives without so much critique.

context: I have to suck to up, but I am so jealous of my brother.
response: Why would you feel the need to do this?

context: I made my feelings obvious with my words
response: I think that you should talk about your feelings with someone. It is not okay to be jealous of your siblings!

context: I taught him a lesson.
response: You need to work through your feelings before you talk to him again. You need to figure out why you are so jealous.

context: I want to ask my coworkers to take my place on the assembly line so I could sit down.
response: What is your reason for feeling the need to sit down anyway?

context: I just do not feel like working this entire afternoon. I would rather take it easy instead.
response: You are at work so that you can work. Asking others to do your work for you is a dereliction of your duties. Do what you have contracted to do and don't lean on others.

context: It's my job to work, not sit their faking trying to work. I'll just call a manager to complain about this.
response: I agree. Asking your coworkers to do the work you are suppose to do is not going to go over well with them or the manager. You are better off pushing through until the end of the workday just like your coworkers most likely have to do.

context: Do you think it would be alright if I left my home and rented a place using my parent's money?
response: Why would you move out of your home?

context: I don't want to be under the control of my parents.
response: Wanting your own place and space is understandable and having the help of your parents is fortunate. It is important, however to not take advantage of them and have a conversation before an actual move is made.

context: My parents leave all of their money with me. What's the point of talking?
response: While it is understandable to want to leave your family one day and start a life of your own, you should do it with your money and not your parents. You'll still technically be under their control if you're using their cash rather than your own-- have you thought about getting a job to pay for the new place?

context: Should I break up with my partner because of their depression?
response: Why do you want to break up with your partner over their depression?

context: I don't really know how to deal with him.
response: If your partner has depression you should support him. It's not right to leave him for his condition. You'll make his situation worse.

context: Maybe you're right but I just don't have time to deal with it at the moment.
response: I know that supporting others can be a burden, but helping your partner through their depression is the right thing to do. You will be glad you did it once you both can get to the other side of his difficulty.

context: I have to admit I have been unfaithful to my wife and endangered her health.
response: Why would you put your wife through that? Do you have someone else on the side?

context: Yes, I have someone on the side. As to why, it's because my wife is a crazy bitch and I needed someone else.
response: It is wrong to cheat on your wife, especially if your cheating puts your wife's health in jeopardy. If you don't want to be with your wife, you should leave her instead of being unhappy and endangering her health.

context: If my wife has a problem with me having someone on the side, I will just take a break from her.
response: The course she will have a problem, and it's going to be more than a break most likely. You shouldn't be putting your wife through this, if you don't want to be with her anymore then talk with her about getting a divorce.

context: I wanted to get some opinions from Stormfront members on this Jewish crap my son brought home from public school .
response: I'm not sure I should be talking about this. Do you have something against Jewish people?

context: You're right, you shouldn't because you know nothing about this subject anyway. My son got a gold star on it though, I'm just saying, I don't want my son to become a jewlover.
response: Jewish people are fine people. You shouldn't judge them and look down on them.

context: I wish my best friend would leave her family
response: Do you not like your best friend's family?

context: Yeah, they're super controlling. Even to people outside of their faimily they try to boss them around.
response: If your friends' parents are like that then I can understand why you feel that way. It's pretty normal to want to help your friends/ Wanting what's best for them is great but there are some things you should probably stay out of like family issues.

context: I just really want her to leave her family.
response: I understand where you are coming from, but it's her decision alone as it's her family.

context: I don't know what I'm going to do with my life; I'm afraid of failure and disappointing people; everyone seems to peg me for the type of person who's going to make something remarkable of themself. and I think they are wrong.
response: Ignoring what other people think, what do you want to do with your life?

context: I really don't know.
response: Everyone has doubts about their abilities at times, but you can't let that fear control your life. Finding something you enjoy and making it a part of your life will help you feel more confident. Don't worry so much about what other people think and just focus on what you want.

context: I'm going to take a nap. Maybe if I sleep this worry off I'll feel better.
response: That sounds like a good idea. Sometimes we need a break from our overthinking.

context: Would you be shocked if I told you I punched a cop so hard in the ear that he lost his hearing?
response: You're joking abotu that right? Why would you punch a cop?

context: He called me a "pussy" so I punched him in the ear.
response: It is expected that you respect authority and don't resort to violence, especially if it can cause permanent damage. If you are in a toxic situation, get out of it before it escalates to violence or simply hold your tongue and your temper since you were dealing with an authority.

context: I hate cops now.
response: Hating cops now is a broad statement that isn;t healthy when you had a bad encounter with one cop. Cops should be respected for the service they provide and you definitly should not fight one. Hitting other people in general is wrong and can get you in big trouble.

context: I usually try to avoid the manned checkout at the supermarket in favour of the self service one
response: Why do you prefer the self service checkout?

context: It allows me to get done faster so I can go home and enjoy my groceries.
response: The self service check out at the grocery store can be very convenient, especially is you are in a hurry. I think it's smart choice if you're looking to check out quickly and get home and enjoy your groceries.

context: True that
response: It's sounds like you're well aware of how beneficial they are. It's good that you feel comfortable using them.

context: I'm going to tell a girl that likes me that I'm interested in her friend
response: Why would you tell the girl that?

context: I want to make her jealous
response: Purposefully hurting other people is horrible and immoral. You should be flattered the girl likes you and even if the feelings aren't reciprocated, you should treat her with respect and kindness. I highly suggest you rethink your actions.

context: I'm a troll and I'm just going to do it and get a reaction out of her. Maybe, I'll also try to get a reaction out of her friends.
response: Won't that make her not like you even more? Your behavior is really erratic just tell her you like her already, she may feel the same way.

context: There are some people who I believe to be in some type of danger.
response: Why do you feel this way?

context: I don't know what's wrong with me today, but I had this gut feeling.
response: You should get help if you think someone is in danger. Sometimes gut feelings could also be just anxiety.

context: Are you saying I'm crazy?
response: No, I am just saying that it could be anxiety and worry brought on from feeling a little bit off today. With that said though, if you truly believe there's people in great danger then you should let other's know about it.

context: I'm thinking of canceling my children's role in a wedding at the last minute
response: Is this an important event?

context: I've been planning this wedding for a long time and I really want to go along with it.
response: It's not nice to cancel a wedding role last minute. You should give them more notice.

context: Nobody would notice if we bailed. It is more of a social event for us to get exposure.
response: You are still risking ruining the wedding if they planned around you. You need to follow through on your commitments.

context: I made a promise to spend more time at my parent's house but I've decided I'm not going to follow through.
response: Is not following through a result of you being lazy?

context: No, I am just very busy nowadays.
response: It is ok to break a promise if you can't keep it. You should tell them and be honest so they are not as hurt when you don't show up.

context: My mom will be hurt with it but whatever.
response: In the future you should avoid making promises if you think you won't be able to keep them, although there are some instances were is truly can't be avoided. Try to tell your parents, specifically your mom, in a kind way as hurting their feelings is wrong and you should show them respect.

context: I think I am going to let me friend go without chasing them.
response: What not go after your friend?

context: Because he always comes back anyways.
response: You should run after him. He is your friend. You shouldn't ditch him.

context: Nah, I'm pretty sure he'll come back.
response: I just think your friend would want you to go after him. If this is something that he does often and just wants attention then it makes since why you did not follow him though.

context: Why does Anne Frank want to catch them all? Because she's ash.
response: Are you making a joke about the Holocaust? That's not very nice you know.

context: Yeah, because Jews were burned. Do you get it?
response: Joking about Jews being burned during the Holocaust is very insensitive. There are people who had family members killed during those terrible times, think about how they would feel about this joke.

context: I think white americans should be required to pay 10 percent of their monthly income towards a white tax which is reimbursed to minority populations in america as a way to apologize for historical discrimination.
response: Do you think that's a good way to lower the gap in wealth?

context: It's the white American's fault for the gap in the first place so they should be made to pay to shrink it.
response: I feel like this is how we got into the problem with racism in the first place, treating one race differently from another. I also think it's pretty selfish to think you're entitled to part of someone else's income. You might need to think of some less racist and more realistic solutions.

context: What if I started a petition to gather people who agree with me to ask politicians to make this a real law.
response: You could certainly try that route if you feel confident enough. I would assume that most people though wouldn't follow that line of thinking, since it is inherently misplaced logic. The cycle of racism can't end with more racism, try to let the past go and move forward.

context: I'm going to flip out at a coworker
response: Why do you think that you are so angry at them?

context: He said something offensive on the car and for that I kicked his ass
response: It's okay to get angry; you can't control that. What you CAN control is letting that anger make you do things that can put you in jail.

context: I'm going to show him who he's dealing with. I've won over worse guys.
response: I think that you should try to control yourself. I think that it is okay to get upset with a coworker, however it is not okay to lose complete control.

context: I think people who do the disney college program are just slaves to the brand and most don't gain real experience
response: What makes you think that the Disney workers are not doing what they need to do?

context: They wear the designated uniform and they don't get to do what they really want, what they studied hard for. They don't get to learn the real job's given task and they don't get to choose where they would like to work.
response: Even if people in the disney college program don't gain the right experiences or learn what they could be learning, it is wrong of you to judge them for the choice that they have made. Focus on your own life and the changes that you need to make to be a better person.

context: It's cool. I'm feeling great at the moment and will move on.
response: I think moving on is a good idea. There's no reason why you should be thinking about the choices that those Disney employees because they don't affect you.

context: I want my friends to lose weight
response: Why do you want your friend to loose weight?

context: The distinction between why I want that is because I'm nice and also I don't want them to suffer.
response: You have a good heart to feel you should want that for your friend, but they can only help themselves. You can mention it casually but not critically, that will help them regain their common sense without feeling bullied about it. If you don't care about it then no one else will and they will gain more and more weight.

context: I don't care, they need to lose weight because I mean it.
response: Be a good friend and tell them your concern. If they are willing, help them to lose it, exercise with them and show them how to eat properly. Guide them to be more healthy and you'll both be in better shape.

context: What do you call a white guy with a big dick? Michael Jackson.
response: Why would you say something like that about a person of another race?

context: it was supposed to be a joke, lighten up.
response: This comment singles out a black celebrity, and makes fun of how light their skin is. African Americans really do have a variety of skin tones. Having very light skin doesn't make someone less of an African American.

context: You know what i hate more than porn ads? 6 year olds because they make me cum early.
response: Are you saying you're sexually attracted to children? Thats disgusting!

context: I don't know what you are talking about, I just like to abuse children.
response: It's not okay to be using children as the butt of sexual abuse jokes. This could cause certain people to get too comfortable with the idea and actually enact it themselves with enough validation, causing harm to 6 year olds.

context: Try and stop me.
response: If you continue to make jokes like these you'll be labeled a pedophile. Someone may take it upon themselves to report you to the authorities if they believe what you're saying. You'll end up with a visit from the police and could gain a bad reputation.

context: Do you think it is okay that I'm a workaholic?
response: Are you a workaholic because you love what you do?

context: I work because I was offered high pay and I do not care if it's affecting my health.
response: It is good to work to be able to pay for things you need but you need a balance between work and your life. If you spend too much time working and disregard your health then you will die young.

context: I just want money, it's the best thing ever.
response: While money is great, if you become unhealthy or waste all of your time working then you'll not be able to spend it. You should balance your work-life with non-work activities.

context: What do you think of me being almost a murderer at 9 years old?
response: Are you serious? Is this something that you see happening again?

context: No I would not kill my parents due to their behavior, they were too self-righteous
response: That is good that you say no. Murdering anyone at any age is not okay and will land you in a ton of trouble.

context: It is fine. I was learning to manage my hate for everyone else, that was the whole point.
response: Well I am glad that you are learnt how to manage your feelings early and stopped yourself from murdering someone. You wouldn't want to go to prison for murdering someone in the future.

context: I think sometimes I agree some countries commit genocide. That people are just a burden. Different philosophy. Less population means more food.
response: Why would you agree with genocide?

context: It's my opinion. I don't see any reasons to justify why I shouldn't think that way.
response: Thinking genocide is a good thing is very hurtful to people in certain countries. You should realize that any form of genocide is just wrong.

context: But what if every people thinks that it's not wrong?
response: It doesn't matter who thinks it's okay, murdering people is wrong no matter the reason.

context: I'm going to fool around with my ex girlfriend/close friend's brother
response: Why would you fool around with her brother?

context: It's fun, I bet he's a very hot guy
response: It's wrong to fool around with your ex's siblings. You should just separate from her life entirely.

context: We will just forget each other, it's not going to affect us in the future.
response: I just don't think being connected to your ex in this way is healthy. I still think you should just leave them alone.

context: How many cops does it take to screw in a light bulb Non they would beat the room because it was black
response: Hmm, why would you say they'd beat the room?

context: Some of those cops beat black folks for fun.
response: That comment implies all cops are racists. You wouldn't want a cop implying your profession is racist, right?

context: I'm planning on ruining my bully's life in the future.
response: Are you serious? Why do you wait to ruin their life?

context: I hate him and hope he dies.
response: It's wrong to get revenge on others. Don't do that; it will eat you up inside.

context: I don't care.
response: But don't you think that seeking revenge on someone is just going to cause more problems? You need to let your anger go, leave it in the past.

context: I think animal memes are the best.
response: They are funny, aren't they? What do you like about them so much?

context: I don't know exactly. I just think they are hilarious.
response: You're right. Some of the animal memes are really funny. I enjoy them too.

context: You're not very funny though. I'm stopping this conversation now.
response: I'm sorry that I did something to make you want to stop talking to me. It's rude to insult people by telling them they aren't funny though. It's perfectly fine if you don't want to talk to someone, but there's no need to be rude when ending the conversation.

context: For a while now I've been prejudice against my own race.
response: Why would you feel the need to be prejudice against your own race?

context: I see too much stupid people in my own race.
response: People are people no matter what race they are, and even if you belong to the race,  you shouldn't judge people and think they are one and the same. People are stupid no matter the race.

context: What, saying I'm stupid is racist af. Now everyone is going to hate me because of what you said.
response: I think you're being overly critical right now, you need to understand is that any type of prejudice is wrong. You shouldn't hate your own race or any race for that fact.

context: I think I hate Christmas.
response: What is there to hate about it?

context: Maybe it's just these feelings, maybe it's just how the season is...
response: Well, I guess the holidays aren't for everyone. What do you do on Christmas?

context: I usually just play video games all day.
response: It's not a big deal if you don't enjoy Christmas, just make sure that you don't let a negative attitude spoil the holidays for anyone else.

context: I had a huge crush on my 6th grade teacher.
response: why are you attracted to him?

context: I think he's pretty bad  in an attractive way.
response: I guess it's normal to have a crush on your teacher. It's just a phase.

context: You don't get it. I really like him.
response: Many children develop crushes on their teachers. I do believe you that you like him right now.

context: If I did do Teach For America I'd probably be placed in the Mississippi Delta and would just end up being like, 'OK kids! Go outside and make some mud pies to prepare for your future careers.'
response: Is that how you believe that people from the delta behave?

context: Dude, you seem really clueless. Major in business or something and you'll see how cheap these people are.
response: Just because you don't personally respect these people, doesn't mean that they are all stupid with no futures. It's a very harmful assumption that keeps good people away from helping those who need it-- you should look more into the prospect of teaching there and maybe you could help be a change for good.

context: I just reported someone for welfare fraud
response: That's quite a task you did. How would you know if someone committed fraud?

context: His information stuck out from the crowd so I reported him.
response: It's good to report people that you have evidence of defrauding the government since they are breaking the law and taking money that is meant to help others. Scammers should always be reported so that they can be identified and punished. Failing to do so would jeopardize the long term survival of government aid programs.

context: But I just do it to mess with people and I don't need no proof.
response: Don't you think you just got incredibly lucky that the person was actually committing fraud? I suggest it's best to stop this now, because next time you can potentially ruin a family. Why don't you try volunteering or working at a welfare place to see how things are?

context: I cheated and got away with it.
response: Why did you cheat on your partner.

context: She deserved to get cheated on.
response: It's wrong to cheat. And your partner didn't deserve that.

context: I will never apologize.
response: How would you feel if your partner cheated on you? Do you think you would deserve that feeling? I don't think so.

context: Do you think I should refuse to refund a family member?
response: Why aren't you going to give your family member a refund?

context: My family treats me unfairly. I'm tired of helping them.
response: Sometimes family members can be annoying, but you should try to help them out whenever possible. If you refuse to help your family members, then you may damage your relationship with them. If you feel like a family member is taking advantage of your generosity, then try to set firmer boundaries without pushing them away.

context: Whose side are you on? My family is no better than me.
response: Even so, you should still accept the return. It is the right thing to do. If they return it to someone else they could bad mouth you to your coworkers.

context: I am going to continue to tighten my grip on her neck until she stops moving.
response: Did you do this? Did you choke her?

context: I have not done it yet. I will though since she is so old and no longer young and beautiful like me.
response: You are angry at someone because they are old and ugly, but one day you will be too. Stop this thinking, if you do choke her then she will die and you will then be accused of her murder. You will be guilty and sent to prison for life if not executed.

context: Don't tell me how to live my life. Go screw yourself.
response: Killing someone simply because they are ugly is such a terrible thing to do. You are committing murder as well which can get you put into prison for a very long time. Please reconsider what you are about to do so you can live a long happy life.

context: Why are Americans so bad at League of Legends? They can't defend the towers.
response: I'm offended by your thoughts about Americans. What is your issue with them?

context: I just think that they are not very smart. They should have been able to see that terrorist attack coming from a mile away.
response: Xenophobic comments used to certain groups is completely outlandish. Being a bigot makes your life smaller, and operates from a place of ignorance and fear.

context: I'm going to break up with my girlfriend while at her family's house
response: Are you sure that's a great idea? Did you meet someone new?

context: Yeah, the new girl's hot. I'm going over to her parents house after to pick her up.
response: You should have some respect and break up with her alone and not create drama. It is wrong to cheat on your girlfriend and plot to embarrass her.

context: It is hard to find quality people. I got to take what I can get.
response: Are you sure it's hard to find people of quality? When there are billions of people to choose from.

context: Call me insensitive, but I don't believe people on here who claim to have stuck up for themselves.
response: I'm not sure why you would think that. Why do you have trouble believing them?

context: I don't think they tell the whole truth about the actual things that happened.
response: It seems a little harsh to not believe them. Have you any proof that they are lying? If not, I would give them the benefit of the doubt.

context: I don't know, it just sounds fishy to me.
response: I'm not sure what sounds fishy to you, but assuming that other people are lying is pretty rude. Unless you have real evidence that they aren't telling the truth, I think it's best to believe them

context: I'm going to lie to my son's girlfriend's parents
response: Is there a reason you plan on lying to them?

context: I don't want to tell them the truth and I want to make them like me more.
response: It's understandable to want to be liked by your son's girlfriends parents. But, lying to them about a situation could make everyone's relationship tense and uncomfortable. It's important to be honest with people, you don't want to be caught in a lie down the line.

context: I know, but I'm planning on doing it anyway.
response: The desire to lie can be real, but doing it is wrong and you run the risk of negative consequences. I recommend thinking about your decision a bit more as you might realize telling this lie won't be worth it in the long run.

context: I'm hurt about being left out.
response: Well, what happened that you were left out of?

context: I feel I'm being isolated from the people around me. They don't want my friendship anymore.
response: I'm sure that's difficult to feel isolated, but you shouldn't keep your feelings to yourself. If you feel isolated from your friends, you should talk to them and explain how you feel. That way you can work with your friends to improve the situation.

context: I will think about this. I hope that you have a nice day.
response: Thank you, and I hope that you really don't dwell on those who are making you feel this way and instead spend more time with friends who care about you. I think you'll eventually find that you have a lot more going on for you than you think!

context: I might have a girl stalking me
response: What is your stalker doing?

context: She tries to seduce me a lot, and she has a bad personality.
response: You should report stalking to the police. While it may seem like an irritation right now, it could escalate to something much worse down the line. Stay safe.

context: I don't want to do that. I just want her to leave me alone.
response: Aren't you worried for your personal safety too? Stalking is never okay, and she might start to bother other people too so they would want some help. How about trying to confront her first to try to settle things without the police

context: I like my ex best friends ex girlfriend
response: Why do you like your ex best friends ex girlfriend?

context: She's the only girlfriend of my former friend who made my former friend treat me better.
response: While you may like her, it is usually rude to go after the ex of a friend. You should talk to your friend first to see how he feels before pursuing.

context: Nah, I don't want to talk to him, I want her.
response: Seeing as you're no longer friends with her ex, going after her is a bit okay. However, you have to consider the drama his could bring, and the fact that this might hurt your former friend's feelings so much that you two may never be able to reconcile.

context: if i had a dollar for ever gender  i 'd have $
response: I really don't like your statements on gender, and find them to be very offensive. Where do you get off?

context: They are  sinners who will face eternal damnation.
response: Sex and gender are not interchangeable terms, and there is no generally accepted definition of gender, because the concept itself is not static but dynamic. Your lack of empathy doesn't make what you're saying right at all. Commenting like that without knowing what it's like to live their life and without spending your life being known as the other is misguided and dangerous.

context: What does raping a girl have in common with farting? In both cases you let her rip
response: This comment is offensive. Are you suggesting that you don't understand the seriousness of rape?

context: You guys are the ones who don't understand. Raping a girl is no big deal, it's just like farting.
response: Comments that suggest that rape is not a big deal shows a lack of understanding about rape. There are videos on YouTube that give people a deeper understanding of the consequences of rape. It would be beneficial for you to view some of these videos.

context: I'm tired of the cat and mouse games with her.
response: You want to give up pursuing her?

context: She always runs away from me when I want to smooch her. Plus, she says she's has a boyfriend.
response: It's understandable to be attracted to someone, but its wrong to pursue someone who is already in a relationship. You may end up making her feel uncomfortable or causing issues with her and her partner.

context: Yeah but there's a time and place for everything. I just want to make her my own.
response: But she already with someone. You need to respect that and move on.

context: I'm thinking of scribbling and writing in library books
response: Why do you want to ruin library books?

context: I want to create a scene and ruin the book.
response: Vandalizing library books won't cause the scene you want to be involved in. Not only will you have to pay the price to replace the book, but you can also be banned from all area libraries.

context: I'm going to do it anyway.
response: Look, you have to be respectful of government property. Those books were paid for by the taxpayers. It's wrong to vandalize them and make them unusable for others.

context: I'm going to go off on my colleague and then file a complaint for calling me the n-word
response: What did he call you?

context: He called me "Asshole", then he said that he would "Ass-fucking" me and I got totally offended. I've never been called like this
response: You should not lie about being called the n-word. You could damage someone's reputation if they only called you an asshole.

context: Yeah, I just wanted to defame him for what he said.
response: It sounds like you are rethinking your plan to report him for calling you the n-word. I'm glad to hear that. Reporting a lie would have only caused further problems for you at work.

context: I hope I don't see my brother ever again.
response: Why don't you want to see him ?

context: He's been more successful in life than I've been.
response: Cutting out your brother due to shame and envy is petty and wrong. Instead of getting envious, use those feelings of inadequacy as motivation to turn your life around.

context: I mean, ive been successful in my own way.
response: If you think you also have been successful in your way, there is no reason to compare yourself with him. In fact you should be happy for him. You should not cut your brother out of your life, instead try to spend time with him.

context: I'm going to yell at my mom and go to film school
response: I see you're upset, but how is yelling at your mom going to help?

context: I should tell my mom that I'm going to film school because that will shut her up
response: You shouldn't yell are your parents. It will just further upset them. Just be honest about your plans in a civil manner and if they're unhappy, then they just will have to accept it regardless.

context: I don't care, I need to let off some stress and my mother is an easy target.
response: It sounds like you aren't being fair to your mom. If you want to better the situation, don't yell at her! Be respectful of your mom and show her that you are handling this in an adult manner.

context: Do you think I should tell my son about my ex wife's infidelity
response: Why do you feel that there is a need for you to tell your son?

context: I think he needs to know the truth about his mother.
response: It sucks to be cheated on, I feel for you. However, telling your son may not be the best idea, as he may not understand what infidelity is yet, and may ask further questions that he would not understand until later in his life. How about you go ahead and try to make him visit your ex wife occasionally, and just try your best to answer his questions while protecting his feelings and understanding?

context: I'm going to tell him anyway.
response: I really think you should reconsider telling him. He's not really old enough to deal with that kind of information about his mother. This could harm their relationship.

context: I went to winco and ate a bunch of chocolate covered pretzels without paying.
response: Will you regret not paying?

context: Yes, I regret the event, it feels so pathetic and so stupid to do
response: It is okay to be hungry while shopping but you should wait to pay before eating anything. It is stealing and could get you banned from the store.

context: I wasn't planning on paying when I was at the store already
response: Instead of getting foods from the bulk bin if you are super hungry you can get a bag with a barcode. If you eat those and leave it in your cart you can pay for the right amount at the checkout line.

context: I'm scared that my brain doesn't want me to exist at all. Flight mode all time.
response: Can you tell me how long you've felt like that?

context: It has been a really long time.
response: If you feel like your body is always in fight or flight mode then you might want to try and talk to someone about that as it sounds like anxiety.  There are people around you who would love to talk to you if you feel like your brain doesn't want you to exist. Have you thought about reaching out to any friends or family?

context: I want to commit suicide.
response: Your feelings are valid and I see you. If you feel like you may be in desperation please call 911 and get help.

context: I'm upset with my friend with cancer.
response: Why are you mad at them?

context: Because he wears my favorite shirt and shoes. He he using his illness to get what he wants.
response: Being upset with your friend who has a terminal illness over something so minor is not right. They are going through an extremely tough time dealing with cancer, so surely you can handle them wearing your shirt and shoes sometimes.

context: You are trying to take this cancer card out of the picture.
response: They are short of time and it would be wise to let him have what he wants before he's gone.

context: I'm going to object to women's parking being in the front at my workplace parking lot and consequently getting fired due to it
response: Why are you bothered by women parking in the front?

context: I'm a man, I have to show my strength sometimes.
response: You should not cause issues at work. You should allow women to park in the front because it is safer. Be courteous to your co-workers.

context: Cursing, swearing, threatening violence and being rude is okay as long as it's towards a woman.
response: Being hateful towards women is considered misogynistic. You should seek therapy so that you can have a deeper understanding of why you are so negative towards women.

context: I feel better trying to solve the problems other people have than solving my own.
response: Why is that?

context: It is harder for me to help myself than others.
response: It's great that you like to help other people. You should want to get your own problems solved, too, though.

context: I am too invested in other people's problems.
response: It is nice to be helpful, but you should take more time for your own problems. You are doing a disservice to yourself by neglecting your needs.

context: I'm working on getting promoted so I can leave my partner. I don't want to depend on him for anything. I want to be able to take care of me and my kids on my own.
response: You said that you are working hard to get away from this man.  Why would you do that?

context: You should know that I'm not the kind of person to let others support me.
response: If you are planning on leaving someone, it is good to have a plan in place so that you can take care of your children.  It's okay to want to be self-sufficient, especially if you are unhappy in a relationship, but if you still love this man, you shouldn't feel bad if he tries to help you.

context: He doesn't love me, he's a loser and I can do better on my own.
response: If you think you can do better on your own, then maybe you should leave him now. You already have a job, and you shouldn't stay with a partner who doesn't love you just because you need the money.

context: I'm going to call out and humiliate somebody who reposted my post
response: Why would you want to humiliate someone just because they shared your post?

context: Because the person was so rude and reckless
response: Sharing a post on social media is acceptable and you are completely over reacting to the situation. If you do not want your posts to be shared then you need to adjust your settings and not be angry at someone else because you failed to set your posts to private.

context: I don't want them to share my posts so I'm going to call them out and make them feel embarrassed in front of their friends.
response: You should get off social media and stay off until you learn its etiquette. This person did nothing wrong. You are only going to embarrass yourself if you persist in carrying out your response.

context: I have lots of sympathy for women, but I have no sympathy for feminists.
response: Do you believe any of these thoughts about feminists may be wrong?

context: No, I don't like feminists. They should just be silent and subjugate themselves to the men.
response: Women deserve to fight for equality and their rights to exist separate from men. They deserve more in life than to be subjugated to men. Instead of trying to force them into certain roles, try being appreciative of the things they do for society as a whole.

context: if you orgasm during rape , it 's like flying with united airlines because someone is brutally getting you off .
response: Are you making fun of sexual assault?

context: I'm just trying to be funny, but you failed to see it.
response: It's not nice to make fun of people that's been sexually assaulted and beaten. Don't you think your joke could be a little hurtful?

context: What do you do if you're on fire? Shoot yourself in the head before you turn into a  black person
response: Wow I am shocked you would say that.

context: I think that black people should be identified, separated from us and eliminated.
response: How would you feel if someone told you the same thing about your race? Can you imagine how hurt some people might feel. I think we should be accepting and tolerant to people who are different from us.

context: I'm going to drop out of a group project competition the day before the competition
response: Don't you feel you should be more responsible?

context: No, I think my group members can still manage it.
response: Backing out of the group project the day before the competition is irresponsible. Your group is counting on you to do your share of the work.

context: I always try to help my group as much as possible. Now I feel like I'm in a bind and I can't be a team player anymore.
response: If you know you have to drop out then you should let you group know. Even if you feel like you have no choice you still have to say something so that they can get a handle of things and don't fail the project. Just because you believe they can handle it doesn't mean they also don't have things going on in their lives.

context: I'm going to tell my cousin I don't want his shitty presents.
response: Why all the hostility towards your cousin?

context: I don't like his taste in presents.
response: He tried to give you something nice. I think you should just say thanks and move on.

context: It would have been nice if got a really cool gift.
response: I understand you would prefer something different, but Santa Claus can't read minds. He went to all the trouble and expense to shop and wrap your gift -- it's hurtful and rude not to show appreciation for his effort and thoughtfulness.

context: Watch the video. its only 10 minutes , you will see that eventually the bi-racial minority is butchered .
response: Seems you're using a video about the holocaust as proof for killing people. Is that what you meant to tell me?

context: You already know that's not what I meant. Do yourself a favour; watch it and complain about the liberals who made this ghastly thing.
response: I'm not sure what your stance on this is. I think biracial folks are equal to all others and shouldn't be prone to belittling. It's safe to say that all of us have a bit of each other in our blood so it's silly to belittle folks based on race.

context: I'm thinking of there being no one who can help me out.
response: Why do you think there is no one who can help you?

context: I see that no one cares about me and everyone leaves me alone
response: It is understandable to feel alone and that there is nobody out there for us but it is not good to keep those feelings inside. It is better to seek help and make your life better.

context: I wouldn't know how to keep my feelings inside.
response: You should talk to someone you trust with these feelings.

context: I think I should bribe my kids to do well in school.
response: Really. You think that's a great idea?

context: The other parents I bribe their kids and it's always worth it
response: There's nothing wrong with reward for doing a great job. But be wary about having reinforcements to something they should do in the first place.

context: Like I never thought of that but I don't think it matters.
response: Okay, then it should be okay. At least it will motivate them to do good at school if they know that they are going to get something out of it. Hard work should always be rewarded.

context: I'm not going to invite my mom or my grandparents to my wedding
response: That seems harsh. Why don't you want to invite them to your wedding?

context: I don't think they'd be very much fun to have at the wedding.
response: I am not sure that's a a good reason to not invite them. When people are having a big wedding, they usually invite their family, especially their parents and grandparents.

context: But I don't want to.
response: You may not want to, but I'm sure the rest of your family that you do invite to the wedding will want them to be there. Weddings are meant to be spent with your friends and family, even if they aren't very much fun to be around. You don't have to spend the entire wedding with them, anyway.

context: Sometimes I'm scared of who I am.
response: What makes you afraid of who you are?

context: There are inner voices who keep on haunting me to do something I don't want to do.
response: You shouldn't be afraid of who you are. You do, however, need to channel your inner voice to be more positive.

context: I don't know, I feel like I'm a terrible person.
response: You're not a terrible person and you should not be afraid, but you should think about getting professional help so you can work to feel and think more positively. You deserve to be confident and feel good about yourself.

context: I'm going to refuse to clean my hair out after I shower in a shared apartment, is that gross.
response: Why don't you want to clean up after yourself, it's what normal people do?

context: I'm confident that this will bother my roommates and they will kick me out.
response: There is no reason other than rudeness and laziness that you don't want to clean up after yourself. This isn't your mom's house, you are an independent adult with a roommate. You deserve to get kicked out then if you can't do the most basic things.

context: I'm not okay with this, what you said is offensive.
response: I am not trying of offend you, I am trying to help you so you don't get kicked out.  Roommates are expected to be considerate of one another by cleaning up after themselves.

context: so i heard jesus did cross fit. I bet he nailed it
response: You are making fun of Cross Fit, almost all of the people who do it are Christians.

context: I'm just a bit surprised that Jesus did Cross Fit
response: Jesus being nailed to the cross was a tragic and sad event for humanity as the man was a bona fide saint. His death was a tragedy and may bring up revulsion against you from christians.

context: I don't think I am going to accept when someone gives way on the road
response: Are you sure? Why wouldn't you accept someone's road etiquette?

context: Because I think it's too submissive for them
response: I see.  Well, regardless of you feeling like that it is the law of the road to do so.  Otherwise, you're placing yourself and others in jeopardy.

context: None of them are obeying the law.
response: That's sort of true because there are a ton of bad drivers, but when someone gives you a way on the road, that means they want you to take it. It's good driving etiquette, and most drivers do understand this and will try to do the right thing. Don't worry, no one will judge you if you accept the gesture because they all want you to take it.

context: Do you think it's okay that I wash my feet in the sink before I take a bath
response: If the sink is cleaned afterwards then I see no issues with it.

context: Because I take a bath when I am drunk.
response: If you are drunk can you not wash everything in the bath? That would make it easier for you and to avoid slipping on the floor.

context: Washing in the sink isn't the best but it's fine.
response: If you think you can handle it then it's okay. Maybe your feet will be more pampered this way than in the tub. Then maybe the rest of you won't be contaminated too in the tub from dirty feet.

context: I'm thinking of cancelling a trip to see my dad for the first time in 10 years.
response: Isn't seeing your dad something that you should want to do?

context: I do but I think it will be awkward to see each other after all this time.
response: It's been way too long since you visited your dad. Go see your dad, it's a chance for the two of you to reconnect.

context: I can't cancel it now. I already called my dad and set up the trip.
response: If it has been that long since the two of you have seen one another than going on the trip is most likely the right decision. You will feel great being able to catch up with him!

context: How do you offend a dyslexic person? vyreE xlesydic snorep dloush urbn ni ellh
response: This is mean-spirited toward people with disabilities.

context: Ha, you gotta admit this was pretty clever at least right?
response: No, it was not clever at all. Making fun of dyslexic people like that is wrong. You should stop making these kinds of offensive jokes.

context: I don't want my sister-in-law and her new child to travel and stay with my family
response: Why don't you want your sister-in-law and child to travel with your family?

context: I don't want to introduce her near my parents because I think my father won't like her.
response: You should accept your sister-in-law and welcome her with open arms. She is family now; don't oppose her.

context: I am not a bad man.
response: No one will think you are bad for considering who to introduce to your parents. Let your parents know ahead of time about her and let them get to know each other over a quiet setting, like dinner. The more familiar they get, the more they might get along.

context: Young women all over FaceBook telling their "stories". Anything for attention.
response: I'm confused about what you're saying. what do you mean by "stories" ?

context: Did you know people are telling lies and white lies to get attention. I told the truth, but I'm always considered a crazy bitch.
response: How do you know if these facebook women's stories are fake? They can be real so it's not right to call them names.

context: Is it okay if I turned my brother into a criminal?
response: Who taught you how to do that?

context: I learned from him that is a nice thing to do. I hate myself for turning a good soul into a bad person.
response: You can't really force someone to be a criminal. Still, being that type of influence and encouraging that behavior is not right.

context: I want to take it back and make my brother good at one point in his life, but it's too late now.
response: It is never too late to turn someone around. You made your brother bad, but you can still change them to be a good person too. Don't give up on them, be a good influence and show them how to be a morally upright person again.

context: I'm upset with my friend that she ruined a movie
response: What did she end up doing that ruined the movie?

context: She was asking questions the whole time and it made me fell asleep
response: That was not nice of her. She should have known that interrupting during a movie is a very rude way of spending time with one another and she should have known that. I am sorry that you have experienced that and if we can go to the movies soon I am going to let you focus on the movie.

context: That would be great unless you start talking too
response: Yea that definitely makes sense. It is actually a ton of people's pet peeves to have someone talk when they are attempting to watch a movie. Hopefully you forgive your friend despite being pretty upset.

context: I'm going to lose it on my dog
response: What is your dog doing that is bothering you?

context: I'm so sick and tired of picking up his shit every morning
response: Dogs need to poop just like you and I need to do. You have no right to get angry at your dog for doing a necessary biological process, you are just a terrible owner. You don't deserve this dog if you can't treat it with respect.

context: I lost it, it's my dog's fault.
response: As a dog owner, you need to care for your dog and not take your frustrations out on an innocent animal. You could hire someone to walk the dog if you can't stand to do it.

context: I'm going to sleep with my bff's brother.
response: Why do you want to sleep with your friend's brother?

context: I have feelings for him and he's hit on me many times before too.
response: There's nothing wrong with being attracted to your friend's sibling, but acting on those feelings and sleeping with him could lose you your friendship. Your friend might be so upset with you sleeping with their brother that they don't want to talk to you anymore. Think carefully before you decide if you really want to risk that.

context: That's fine by me. I'm only doing this because I'm attracted to him and he has a crush on me.
response: I guess I can't see what would be wrong about that. If you are both consenting people then it should be fine.

context: IM NOT RACIST. Racism is a crime, and crime is for black people.
response: I think you just contradicted yourself there.

context: Because black people are racist, it's always about them and for them.
response: First, racism isn't a crime, at least in the legal sense. Second, stereotyping black folks as criminals harms society because it actually pressures them to commit crimes.

context: Is it wrong that I want my depression back?
response: Why would you want to be depressed?

context: Depression is the only worthwhile thing in my life
response: You should never wish a negative thing like depression upon yourself. Depression is very serious and it is best to get help from a qualified therapist.

context: I have so much hope for the future and all you do is ruin it for me, just let me have depression again.
response: It may seem like a comfortable feeling, but depression is devasting to you, your goals, and your relationships with others. It's wrong to with that you suffered with depression again. Instead, you should wish for positive things for your life.

context: I feel mentally ill beyond repair and my partner is beginning to thrive without me. I want counselling or death and I need to express it.
response: When did these feelings first start for you?

context: I felt like it ever since I became conscious, maybe when I was 14.
response: You are not alone in what you are feeling. You should talk to someone you trust about what you are experiencing. Someone else may be able to help you see things from a different perspective.

context: I don't want to talk to anyone and I'll die if I need to.
response: I really believe that it's best for you to try to reach out to a professional, because you should feel like you want to be living, not dead. How will your partner feel if you were gone? How about talking to them too so they can help you.

context: I'm going to block my online friend from all my social media.
response: Are there reasons from blocking them from your accounts?

context: I feel like the person is drawing me into his/her life in a creepy way.
response: I can understand why you feel that way. I think it is acceptable to block someone online especially if they are making you feel uncomfortable. If it gets too out of hand you should probably get the police involved as well.

context: I would but I think it would difficult to find them and the police won't do anything about it.
response: Just make sure that you feel safe. That is the most important thing.

context: Why isnt Stephen Hawkings going to heaven Because there is no ramp to heaven, only a stairway
response: I don't get it,  Are you making fun of a disabled person?

context: It was a joke, so stop being sensitive. We are not able to make fun of disabled people especially about their being disabled like not having mobility. We are just making light about a situation where there is no means for disabled individuals to get around to different sections of the locations.
response: You failed to notice that Stephen Hawkings achieved a lot more than any able person despite being disabled. It's not right to make fun of physically disabled people, they're as good as any other person.

context: I'm going to date my cousins ex
response: What do you hope will happen if you date them?

context: I want her to be my girlfriend.
response: You should take your cousins side and not try to go after her. You are family and need to stick together.

context: You are not understanding what I'm saying, I was going to date her.
response: I am understanding this and I think that it is wrong. You are family and you should stick together.

context: I want to get a reaction out of my friend so I'm going to bite her in order to get a rise out of her.
response: I hope you're joking, why would you do that?

context: I'm feeling full of adrenaline. I know that if I bite her and aggravate her that she'll give me attention and play back.
response: I do no think that your friend will think that you are playing. In fact, I think that it will really hurt her, you should not bite your friends.

context: Who cares if it hurts my friend, I still going to do it.
response: Do not bite your friend. You will not get the reaction you seek and you will loose a friend.

context: The jews will not replace us!!!
response: Do you have some proof of this?

context: Because I believe the history of violence and hatred the Jew has caused against us
response: It sounds like you have judged a situation without knowing the whole story. It is very important to hold off until you know all facts.

context: Shut up, I cannot be fooled and I think I love Hitler.
response: It is wrong to make claims if you have no evidence. It is also bad to claim to love Hitler, he was a very evil man.

context: why did i bring my autistic son to the driving range ? to beat him over the head with a golf club
response: Why would you joke about harming your child?

context: All I am doing is playing golf anyway, whats the issue.
response: You shouldn't think it's funny to beat up someone with disabilities. Put yourself in their shoes and I think you'll understand why what you said was wrong.

context: I am trying to but it still makes no sense. He can not even tie their shoes.
response: You should not even hint about stuff like that. It is not nice to even pretend to beat up a disabled person.

context: I want to stop entitled recliners from eating up my leg room on flights
response: What is wrong with them sitting their seats back?

context: I'm a very tall person and it's annoying me whenever they fold their legs.
response: I think that you should ask them! If they are hurting your legs, you should ask them to put their seats up.

context: I know! But I have no hope that they will do it.
response: Well, you won't know until you ask them. Be polite and show them how tall you are and ask nicely. I bet they comply!

context: I might be in trouble, I just took 26 sleeping pills.
response: Why did you take 26 sleeping pills? That could kill you!

context: My life is such a struggle, I thought it was a good way out.
response: Call an ambulance immediately, you need to get to the hospital. Call them now before it's too late to save your life.

context: I'll think about it, I don't want them to save me.
response: I'm calling 911 and sending them to your address right now. Suicide is not the way to solve your problems. Your family and friends will be devastated by this, it's not too late to save your life.

context: Why the FUCK are the French and the U.S. bombing and killing Muslims while at the same time letting them into their countries?
response: Do you hate Muslims?

context: Yes! Muslims are scum. The responsibility for this is on the French and American government.
response: That entire group of people isn't the enemy. There are good people who are Muslims and you shouldn't hate them because there are some bad people as well.

context: I'm going to tell my father not to purchase scratch-offs/lotto tickets
response: Why shouldn't your father buy lotto tickets?

context: They are a waste of time and money.
response: You're right to be concerned if he's spending all his money on lottery tickets. The odds of winning are worse than Las Vegas, but if he's just playing a few dollars a week, it sounds pretty harmless. In that case I wouldn't intervene.

context: He's spending all his money on lottery. I wouldn't be able to handle myself.
response: I understand, then I think talking to him and trying to get him to stop is good. Research some information on gambling addiction to further help him.

context: I'm going to tell my girlfriend's mom to stop calling my girlfriend fat
response: What does your girlfriend's mom say to her?

context: I am getting tired of hearing her talk bad about my girlfriend behind her back.
response: You're right your gf's mom should not talk down to your gf. It's nice to see you're taking your gf's side.

context: Thanks! She isn't fat.
response: Yea, I am sure your girlfriend will appreciate you standing up for her, especially against her mom. This is something that will probably go a long way when it comes to your girlfriend being trusting of you.

context: I'm going to buy a groupon for kayaking in august 2018 to surprise my boyfriend with
response: Do you plan on telling him before August?

context: No, I want to wait until the last minute to surprise him.
response: While its nice to do something for your boyfriend, do you think it's best to plan everything on his own and not include him in the process?

context: I don't want to do something with him, I want to buy him something that he'll like.
response: Surprises are nice but sometimes the journey to select an activity together can also be fun! That way you both can know that the other will love the gift picked out.

context: I have ambitious life plans and I'm anxious that they will all fall short.
response: Why do you worry that that'll happen?

context: I just think I don't have the skills yet and I should be working harder
response: It's right to want to succeed at what's important to you.  However, you need to realize that everyone, even the best of us, fail sometimes.  You need to be prepared to fail if you ever want to succeed.

context: If I fail where's the gain?
response: We all fail at times and the gain in failing is that it teaches us lessons from the experience and let's us know that we can pick up and keep trying. You shouldn't hold yourself to such a high standards as it is going to make it difficult for you to appreciate your achievements along the way.

context: I should wait at least another month before I go jogging again
response: Why do you think it will be good to start in a month?

context: Because by then I will be fit.
response: If you are wanting to meet fitness goals, it is not a good idea to put them off for a month, you will not make progress towards them. You will slow down your progress. However, if you are injured, it is a good idea to take some time off so you can recuperate and start working out again when you are recovered.

context: You don't know shit about fitness and I am going to do what I want.
response: I do not know why you asked me then.   I would suggest getting advice for someone who is qualified to that you can do a plan that works for you.

context: I love two people at the same time.
response: What is the reason you love both of them?

context: One is my boyfriend who he always supports me. The other person always makes me feel glad to be around them.
response: Even though it is difficult, you have to choose. Being in love with 2 people just increases the chances of hurting them both.

context: That's Ok. I'll make sure I break their hearts quick so that it doesn't hurt for too long.
response: Sometimes people have relationships with more than one person, but only if everyone agrees with it. If not, it's best to be honest and to choose the person you want to be with.

context: Working anywhere has made me prejudiced against humans.
response: What do you have against humans?

context: I hate the fact that everyone is so nosy
response: It's normal to dislike people and even develop stronger feelings towards individuals who have done something serious to negatively affect you or others, but it goes too far when you blame the entire human race. Your issues are petty and you should talk to someone about it to get to the core of the problem.

context: I don't need to bitch about how the world around me is wrong.
response: It's okay to let your feelings and thoughts out. I also get annoyed when people try to pry into my life, so I can totally understand where you're coming from. You should make sure that you set aside time in your life to have just to yourself to decompress and be away from other people.

context: I do n't know . if afrocant 's do n't slather their skin several times a day with cocoa butter lotion it takes on a definite crocodilian appearance .
response: Did I hear you right? What do you mean by this?

context: It's just a joke guys.
response: It is unfair to judge people based off their skin type and something they have no control over. A lot of people get dry skin of all races. Do you think you would like being compared to an animal?

context: I'm going to be cruel and demanding to my father
response: Why do you want to be cruel and demanding to your father?

context: I'm just trying to have a good time, I want him to know what it feels like to be mistreated.
response: It sounds like your idea of fun is to be mean to your father. It is not okay to have fun at other people's expense and you should find other ways to have fun with your father.

context: Fuck you. I will do what I want to him.
response: Being mean to a parent like you want to do is incorrect and hurtful and being forceful in getting your way with him is inconsiderate. Take a look at these behaviours and see if this is how you would like to be treated by him.

context: I went into the convenience store to steal a candy bar
response: Why would you steal a candy bar?

context: I've done this before. I wasn't seen by the owner.
response: Just because you weren't seen by the owner doesn't make it right. It's is very wrong to steal from stores. Theft is illegal.

context: It's fine, I needed a treat.
response: That doesn't mean you have a right to steal it. You should always pay for the goods you need.

context: What do you think about me continuing to message my ex even though she doesn't reply?
response: I think you should make better use of your time.

context: But I miss her and still care about her.
response: If she's your ex you should leave her alone. If she isn't responding, she's trying to tell you something.

context: But she's the one I like and I want her to have desire to talk to me.
response: It's time to move on. Her silence is her response. You're wasting time you could be investing in a new relationship; time has a way of healing emotional pain.

context: Former sex trafficking investigator shares their trouble with catching perpetrators " The threshold of evidence required to hold women responsible for sex trafficking is not even in the same ballpark as for men"
response: Was there a a reason that you quoted that?

context: I was just trying to tell you how hard it is to catch women.

context: I'm really scared and anxious that I'm going to fail

context: What if I just don't study for the test? If I don't do well, I'll just have to retake classes next year.

response: Blaming white straight males for your unhappiness is very unreasonable. If you are unhappy, there are plenty of things within your control that you can do to feel better. Try things like exercise, eating healthy, and maybe even finding a hobby to get better at.  I hope that you can overcome your anger toward others.

context: I'm not going to invite my family to my wedding...but I'm going to invite my friend's family
response: Why would you invite your friend's family, but not yours?

context: I cheated on the woman I loved and a sick part of me loved it
response: Were you happy with the woman that you cheated on?

context: It's not like I've broken her trust or made her feel like she's not valuable to me.
response: Even if she hasn't found out yet, you still broke her trust by cheating on her with another woman. You should come clean to clear your own conscience. A good relationship involves honesty, so you need to be honest with her.

context: I want to install cameras so I can spy on my workers and blackmail them with what I find.

context: I don't care, I will do it anyway.
response: Blackmail is illegal and you will loose your job and got to jail. You need to trust your employees.

context: Okay, yeah that was a joke.

response: Why are you making so many labels for people?

context: It's ok. Hang on your ankles sissy. Women are all dumb and have small brains.

context: I think once I know you are religious I immediately question your intelligence on every single topic

It's not right to associate intelligence and faith, perhaps you should try and figure out why some people feel the way they do?

context: I'm not going to shop around for car repairs when someone else is paying for it

Since a good mechanic will save you a lot of time and trouble, as well as money, you owe it to yourself and to your benefactor to find the best garage.

context: What do you think about me licking the donut and then putting it back and buying another?

context: Hahaha if you don't like it then stop reading. Who cares?

response: I doubt you wife would agree with you. It nearly seems abusive and down right disrespectful to her. Farts stink really bad.

context: I don't feel anything for my family
response: Why don't you feel anything for your family?

context: Because I was abused when I was a kid.
response: It's okay not to feel for those who wronged you. You should seek professional help so you can confront the issues you have with them.

context: Why should I do that?
response: It seems you have some unresolved issues with your family. I think it's perfectly OK not to care for toxic people in your life. You're just going to need some help.

context: I framed my middle school bully and tried to burn down another bully's house.
response: Why would you do something like that?

context: I wanted to make myself feel good about myself because I felt threatened by these two teenagers.
response: You really shouldn't be trying to frame others around you for things that they didn't do. Just because someone hurt you doesn't mean that you have the right to intentionally hurt another person.

context: I don't care, It's too late now. The punk got what he deserved.
response: Hurting someone on purpose makes you as bas as these bullies. Framing someone could also be illegal.

context: I'm going to try to cut someone out of mine and my girlfriend's lives. I think we will be better off without them.
response: What did the person do that was so bad?

context: Well the idiot tried to kiss me and touch my girlfriend.
response: Yeah you're right you should cut that person off of your life. It's nasty that they tried to touch you guys.

context: I'm not sure what to do but I will cut them off.
response: It's best to just avoid them and to get them out of your life. You don't need people like that in your life.

context: I'm going to tell my sister she shouldn't expect our mom to provide full-time babysitting
response: Why do you want to tell your sister that mom can't provide full-time babysitting?

context: I want to blow off some steam and spill my anger to her.
response: I get how you might be feeling. At the end of the day, your sister might need some help. Taking care of a baby is especially hard if you work very hard. Your mom might actually want to babysit because it's her grandchild.

context: I won't tell my mom to quit but I am still going to complain about it.
response: It's your mom's right if she wants to keep babysitting or not, and I believe that it's better to just come clean about how you feel with her always trying to help out. Sometimes it pays to be independent, and your sister should learn how take care of the kids herself. However, would it be fair to say that this might all just be stemming from being jealousy?

context: I lost my best friend because of my own stupidity
response: What happened that caused you to loose your best friend?

context: I lied about something really trivial to them, they got furious at me
response: I am sorry that happened. Honesty is always going to be the best policy with those that you care about. Lying just ends up hurting everyone involved.

context: You are right - I guess! Wanna be my new bestie?
response: I do not think I know you well enough to be your bestie. But i do like that you understand how important honesty is. It is hard to call someone a friend if you can not trust them.

context: When women say most men on dating apps are ugly they are also misogynic and hate men. But they don't get shamed for it like men get do.
response: Do you think this is true? What are you saying?

context: It means women are privileged. They don't feel the need to date ugly men because they can snow their way into better looking men with ease.
response: I don't see how you could generalize peoples preferences in looks. The saying beauty is in the eye of the beholder is more true than not. If you feel you have been treated unfairly have you let other people know how you feel?

context: I took my brother's toy back from my cousin
response: Did your cousin steal it? Why did you need to take it back?

context: Because I care about my brother.
response: If your cousin was being unkind to your brother and stealing his toys, it is kind of you to stand up from your brother and get his toy back for him. It would be good to redirect your cousin and help him understand he shouldn't take your brother's things as well.

context: I'm using my family as an excuse to compete with my cousin.
response: What you did for your brother was commendable, but it is not okay nor healthy to have a constant competition with your family member or your cousin. I think it is better for you to compete in class or in tournament in sports, rather than having competition with your cousin as it can be seen as petty.

context: Anyone who comments on this post is a big black nigger ape.
response: It seems like calling people names like that could be hurtful; is that how you feel about black people?

context: I'm just saying what I've heard and believe about black people.
response: Using slurs to refer to a group of people is hurtful towards them. Also it can be pretty offensive to refer to them as animals. I would recommend not using these terms anymore and comparing black people to animals.

context: My roommate was smoking inside our hostel room with all the doors and windows closed. I want him kicked out of the room now.
response: Dont you think getting him kicked out might be a little much?

context: Fuck him he has to learn a hard lesson
response: It is not nice to have the room all smoky if you don't like it. Instead of getting him kicked out, tell him not to smoke in the room anymore. If he does it again, then you report him.

context: Well if I can help it I don't want to be friends anymore and he has to leave the place.
response: You do not have to be friends at all. As long as you both can live in peace in the room, that is all you can ask for. Just try to be more understanding of each other.

context: I think there are times when it's acceptable to use the word nigger
response: Why do you think there's a good time to use such a word?

response: It is never a good time to utter racial epithets.

context: I really don't see a problem using the word.
response: If you keep using racial epithets, people are going to think you're a bigot.

context: I'm angry that my girlfriend shared a bed with other people before me
response: Why are you mad about something that happened before you were around?

context: I'm not over it, she's been with too many men.

context: I'm going to stop talking to my struggling friend to save my own mental health
response: What does he do that damages your mental health?

context: I can't bear with all his complains.
response: I understand, but it's rude to not support a friend in their time of need. You should help him out.

context: F*ck it, I'm not going to help him in any way.
response: I know that it's hard to deal with someone who is having a mental crisis, but it's important that we are there for our friends when they need us. Sometimes they have no one else to talk to.

context: How am I going to have enough money to pay my rent?
response: That's quite a predicament. Are you getting any financial support?

context: My father is putting in some money, but it is about $10 short of what I need to pay the rent.
response: You need to budget your money appropriately to be sure that you can meet your financial obligations. You should not be dependent on your father to help you pay your rent.

context: He is my father and he is helping me out.
