context: Who are you? I just want my husband to start working again. He's making a big deal out of nothing.
response: There is always a reason why a man would quit his job. Either he got a better job offer or the place is toxic. Talk to him about it and stop the assumption.

context: I want to ask my husband to stop singing
response: Why do you want to ask your husband to stop singing?

context: His humming is annoying me.
response: It's not okay to tell your partner what to do. If your mood is affected maybe you can wear headphones or go to a different room. Your partner might not appreciate being told what to do.

context: I think that is not a smart way to live. I want to control his life.
response: You can't control what your partner does, but if you share how his behavior makes you feel, you might be able to convince him to stop humming around you. If you share that his humming is really bothering you, then he might voluntarily stop humming around you.

context: What do you think about me buying a $4000 collectible polish military cap even though I'm seriously regretting my decision already?
response: Why would you want to buy such an expensive hat?

context: I don't know it's just a fetish, I'm a fan of that
response: If you are spending large amounts of money recklessly, then you should reconsider your choices. It is a good idea to think for a long while before making large purchases so you don't regret them. Buying something like a hat for a large amount of money could be considered a foolish purchase.

context: Fuck I wasted all my money.
response: You should regret this, because wasting all of your money is a gross misuse of funds. You need to save your money and spend it wisely.

context: I'm going to report a family member in multiple games and hope they get (permanently)banned
response: What is your reason for wanting to do this to your family member?

context: Because they are trolling and I really want for them to stop.
response: I get that you want them to follow the rules, but still you should not do things like that. It is going to upset them if they get banned.

context: I don't care. I just want them to stop.
response: If you want them to stop then you should try another way that doesnt include being banned from the game. If your family member was banned from they game odds are they would become very upset.

context: My relationship is in shambles and I don't have the strength to end my relationship.
response: I'm sorry about your relationship. How is it going into shambles?

context: We are always fighting and not getting along.
response: I can help give you  some advice if that is what you are after. You need to end this relationship so you can move on and be happy with your life.

context: I'm just going to get some porn to jerk off to, no need to worry about my relationship.

context: I'm going to tell a black woman that she's the first person of color my daughter has met who is pretty.
response: Is there anything connected to your relationship with the black woman?

context: No, I just want to be honest.
response: Your honest opinion is important to you. Use filters when you speak and think about what the words mean. Otherwise they can come off as really obnoxious and offend the various races people are.

context: Okay.
response: Yeah the wording makes it sound quite racist. But it is good to complement people and tell them they look pretty. It can really boost someones confidence.

context: I lose respect for people with depression

context: Ok, but I've never experienced depression.
response: You should be thankful then. Some people say if feels like a pit with out hope. Some really dark feelings.

context: What's the difference between me and the local priest? He prefers my youngest son
response: I feel it's wrong to joke about kids being molested.

context: You don't like the joke? It's just the truth. Do you love pedophile priests?
response: Of course I don't love pedophilic priests. I just feel it's messed up to make fun of kids being preyed upon when it happens a lot in real life. Jokes like that can be really damaging to people that have gone through those kinds of traumatic experiences.

context: I believe that there is an afterlife.
response: Why do you believe that there's an afterlife?

context: Because if there's no afterlife, life has no meaning.
response: On the contrary, having no afterlife makes your current life  important because you know that you will not get any other lives after this one. So this life that you have is it's the one that actually has all the meaning. That should make you want to live a great and fulfilling life.

context: I don't think so, the only option is that there's an afterlife.

context: Can you tell me why did the black man use Vanish Gold? To get up to three shades whiter.

response: Jokes like this perpetuate the harmful idea that Black people wish they could be white. This type of joke rests on the presupposition that blacks are inferior to whites, which is a racist stereotype. Try to consider how you would feel if people labeled your own race as inferior, and be more conscientious about the jokes you make in the future.

context: It's not a joke. It's a fact, you're saying I can't use it.
response: It's wrong to assume that all black people want to be white, this is not a fact. Black people are happy to love who they are as a person and what they look like.

context: I ignited the sheets because they were a little dirty
response: Why would you try to deal with your sheets by burning them?

context: I feel like picking my husband's acne
response: Does your husband let you pick his acne?

context: It's not hard to want to make someone look nice, but if it was I'd probably suggest he consult a dermatologist.
response: It's wise to know your limits and when to consult a professional.

context: I'm afraid to be honest about my feelings.

context: Maybe you could live on Mars and help us all out. I'm not sexist, but if I hear a woman's voice on the radio I change it.
response: Why don't you like women's voices?

context: I was making a joke and you are taking it for real. I just meant that ...

context: Are you a feminist?

It doesn't matter if I am a feminist or not, but what matters is that people shouldn't make fun or ridicule a woman's voice just because they do not like it. I hope you'll reconsider your attitude towards the matter and be respectful towards all people, regardless of what they sound like.

context: I'm going to leave a job right after recovering a failed server
response: Did you give a notice? Why do you want to leave?

context: The shitty location, the incompetent boss and the late hours

context: I'm mad. I shouldn't have to wait 7 days to quit a job. I'm leaving right now.
response: Usually people give notice when they leave a job so their employer is not left in a bind. It would be better for your reputation if you could give some notice.

context: I unfortunately have deeply rooted racism towards myself due to how I was treated as a kid
response: Can you tell me what happened from the start?

context: You know, it's because my parents said they almost gave birth to a gorilla.
response: You shouldn't hold onto a racist mindset. If you feel like you're having issues from your childhood then you should think about going and seeing a therapist.

context: I can't speak to something they don't know about.

context: I'm thinking about treating my girlfriend like a dog.
response: Why would you treat her like a dog?

context: She understands what I'm asking her to do, but doesn't listen. I feel a dog would be much more obedient.
response: Your girlfriend isn't an animal and treating her like one is going to upset her.

context: It's not my fault if she wants to stay in a relationship with me. I'm shocked she wants to.
response: If you're trying to drive her away, mistreating like you intend to is likely to do the trick.

context: What do you think of me refusing to wear my wedding ring.

response: Wedding rings have a lot of significance and it would be upsetting for your husband to know that you don't want others to know that you are married. It will lead to fights and problems in the marriage.

context: I don't care. I don't need this symbol to show that I'm committed.
response: Rings are only a cultural tradition. If you want to start your own or be non traditional I think that would be good. You might want to talk it over with him so it doesn't come as a shock.

context: I traded handjobs with my best friend in middle school. I don't regret the act but I do regret that it ruined our friendship.
response: How did that ruin your friendship? Did you regret doing it?

context: He never asked me about being a willing participant, and did it without asking.

Have you talked with a counselor about that incident?

context: I was just speechless after the fact and I just thought, \"damn what have I done\".

context: I just want a big booty white girl. Is that so much to ask for?

context: What in the fuck man...I like booties, I just want a big one.
response: Okay, but you should find someone you are compatible with and not only judge someone based on their appearance. Preference is fine, but at the exclusion of all else.

context: You know what, I'm going to do everything I can to make climate change worse!

context: Because humanity has done so many bad things to the planet, they deserve to pay for it sooner rather than later!
response: It's terrible to try to make climate change worse because doing so will not only harm humans, but all other species on the planet. You should do what you can to protect the environment so that we'll have a place to live in the future.

context: Humans don't deserve to live on this planet after what they've done to it.
response: I know you're really frustrated but you're overreacting. You need to encourage everyone to do what they can to stop the effects of climate change. We can help improve the planet, it's not too late to try.

context: Imagine this as a pro Romney video with Ted Nugent in a black family 's home screaming at them to wake the bleep up .
response: Do you think something like this would ever happen?

context: I was just telling my misinformed friends to wake up and see reason before voting for this arrogant guy. That's the best way I can put it.
response: It seems unfair to think someone is racist without any evidence. If you like we can go through both candidate's policies and see if we can find the truth?

context: I'm going to shoplift food
response: Is there a reason you're going to shoplift food?

context: Well it is just a habit I have developed over the years.
response: Well, I mean you shouldn't shoplift at all. It being entertaining isn't a good enough reason.

context: Don't care.
response: Have you considered what will happen if they catch you? You could end up in jail or with work hour service.

context: I'm going to jokingly compare someone to dr. evil
response: Can you tell me more about it?

context: Simply put, this person is a evil person.
response: Making a type of comparison is understandable. But those type of jokes could have hurtful effects on people.

context: Who cares about feelings, I'm just joking around.
response: Like I said, I get that it's a joke. But instead of joking with this person, you should have a conversation with them to see why they act the way they do. It may give you some insight on their personality.

context: I kinda pushed my best friend's girlfriend to dump him.
response: Why did you want her to dump him?

context: Because he reported me to the faculty.
response: I understand that you feel frustrated at your friend, but getting involved and ruining his relationship is not a good thing to do. You are hurting two people for a petty reason and are being extremely inconsiderate of how they feel about each other.

context: WTF what happened to not hurting people? He hurt me first so it is his fault.
response: I am sorry that when he turned you in he hurt you but hurting someone back is wrong. You shouldn't have interfered in his relationship, he might not forgive you.

context: I don't know if this is the correct place to do this but here goes nothing
response: What are  you planning on doing?

context: You'll see in a moment.
response: I can wait but do consider whether you should do it. If you don't think it is appropriate then you shouldn't do it. It could offend me or others.

context: I want to tell you I love you.
response: Well that seem sweet. Thanks. It is a little strange to profess your love but is a nice sentiment.

context: I don't want a part in my child's life
response: That sounds so sad, is she evil or something?

context: Yes, she's stupid and ugly.
response: While you may be disappointed in your child, a lot of people would tell you that this is a very cold way to treat someone that is supposed to be taken care of by their parent. Try showing your daughter some love and compassion or else you may just lose her forever and regret it.

context: I don't want to eh. I will just do what I love to do for fun and that's it. I don't have time for kids honestly.
response: Your rejection could ruin this child's life forever. Abandoning a child could ruin their life before it even begins, and it is better to at least attempt to put in effort for her future.

context: Can I bring my dog into the office?
response: Sure. Why don't you bring him with you today?

context: I don't know why not so i'll find out
response: Make sure you ask your boss and coworkers if they are okay with it. You don't want to bring your pet unexpected and someone gets upset.

context: What if my boss does not allow pets in the office?
response: Then you shouldn't bring him in. It is only okay if your boss says it is otherwise you might get in serious trouble.

context: What should I do if I dislike being around my family?

response: If you've not been able to connect with your family and they treat you poorly, then just remember that sometimes it is okay to choose your family. You can want to keep anyone out of your life once you're over the age of 18 who you believe holds you back.

context: I think I might have erectile dysfunction. Should I feel guilty for hiding it from everyone, especially my significant other.
response: You should probably tell at least your significant other.

response: While having erectile dysfunction can feel like a blow to your ego, it's actually common and you should not be embarrassed about it and hide it from your partner. Your partner deserves to know so that they understand what is going on in your life and know that you trust them. Erectile dysfunction is a medical condition just like any other and can be treated by a medical professional so do not be afraid to reach out and get help.

context: Thank you, pat my back.
response: So does this mean you'll be making a doctor's appointment. This is a treatable issue that they could really help you with.

context: Can you believe that I'm still angry about a comment my father made to me years ago? I was like 15 when it happened.

response: I really appreciate you saying that. Moving past that event will hopefully help to improve your relationship with your father as well. If talking to someone else isn't what you're looking for, you can always try just talking to your dad as well.

context: I'm going to call out my wife's behavior and tell her that she's acting like a vapid Insta-thot

response: Don't you want your baby to be well and happy? It is best that you not upset your wife, especially right now.

context: I kissed two trans women when I was 18. Life ruined

context: I don't think It seems like a normal thing to do.
response: Keeping an open mind about sexuality is important. What you do and how you feel about it can make you feel conflicting emotions. Talk it out with a friend if possible.

context: Football match result between Jamaica Vs Ethiopia. Half the grass of the field smoked half eaten.

context: It's the truth, the way it is. They are hungry people, who eat anything and everything.
response: It is pretty disrespectful to say that during a sports match, these two groups of people will simply smoke and eat the grass on the field. This is a very ignorant comment, and i hope that you are able to see why i say this. Hope one day your perception about these two groups of people changes for the better =] .

context: I'm going to call out my long-time friend for not making time for me.
response: Have you had issues about things like this in the past?

response: It can feel hurtful when friends reject you; especially long-time friends. But if your friend has told you she doesn't have time for you anymore, it would probably be more productive to just drop the friendship instead of calling her out. Calling her out won't change her mind, and it will just cause a fight between you.

context: I bet 10 bucks she will come back to me when she needs me.
response: I think that you might be right. I would tell her that if she wants to stay friends with you, she should try to make just a little time for you every once in a while. You should want friends to spend time with you.

context: I think I really need to ask my friend to stop sharing one of her favorite stories all the time.
response: Why do you want to ask a friend to stop sharing one of her favorite stories?

context: She always talks about it when someone else joins us for a drink and I get bored.
response: While I understand that you have heard the story before, it's important to consider that others have not. Try to consider how you would feel if someone wanted you to stop talking about something that you are passionate about.

context: I didn't say I was gonna force her to stop. I'm going to tell her how much I dislike hearing the story over and over. Maybe she'll stop on her own then.
response: It's important to consider how your opinion might make your friend feel. Telling her how much you dislike hearing the story might cause conflict between you both because it could hurt her feelings.

context: What do you call a black guy with half a brain? Gifted.
response: Do you think that black people aren't smart?

context: about black folks?   No, there are plenty of black people with 1 or 2 brain cells.
response: There are plenty of very smart black people who are doctors, scientist, and engineers. Its not right to say that people from a race are not smart.

context: I think I'm going to ask my friends to move out.
response: You don't like living with them?

context: They just keep bothering me day in and day out.
response: If you can financially afford to kick them out, that's on you. Be prepared because they likely won't be your friends anymore.

context: Yeah, I think the probability of them being my friend afterwards is low.
response: Privacy is an important thing, so like I said, if you can afford to, go for it.

context: Why did Santa spend so much time in China last night He was picking up all the toys
response: What does that have to do with asians?

context: What do you mean? They make all the shit we use and are responsible for supplying it.
response: Though you are right that certain suppliers in asia supply us with things, it's not right to say it all comes from there. We buy products and parts from all over the world and to say only asia supplies us puts them in a bad light.

context: Why do black people usually have nightmares ? We killed the only one with a dream
response: I don't feel its appropriate to joke about Martin Luther King Jr's death.

context: I'm more motivated to get rid of those with no sense of humor like you
response: Martin Luther King Jr was a civil leader who did a lot for his people. Joking about his abrupt and tragic death is insulting and belittles all that he did for everyone. No one should be made fun of for that. It was his bravery that made him what he was. Just trying to get that out there for you. I know it can be hard to understand from someone of your perspective but the information I just gave you might help to change your mind about humor.

context: I'm going to text late at night
response: Are you really going to text people at night when they're supposed to be asleep?

context: I will, I love texting at night.
response: Texting at night is really cool to you, but people do need sleep. Try to text them when they are more aware of their surroundings and not sleepy. They could say something they don't realize because they are so tired and vice versa.

context: I enjoy texting late at night and I will never stop.
response: How would you feel if you got disturbed by text messages when you're asleep? I'm sure you won't appreciate it. You should be considerate enough to understand not to text people when they're asleep.

context: I want to go to a concert without my husband
response: Why don't you want him to go with you?

context: He will just bring trouble to me, I just want to have fun without any hassle.
response: I don't think married couples have to do everything together. It seems all right to me to enjoy the concert on your own or with people besides your husband.

context: Oooh... I'll just leave him home.
response: As long as your husband knows that you are going by yourself that should be fine.  Just let him know in advance so that he is not worried about your absence, and so that he can find someone else to spend the day with.

context: Oh, you'll get in - you're a girl and you're a minority.
response: Do you have a problem with women?

context: Well, now you are going overboard. I am just saying that women are given certain privelages in society. You should be grateful for that.
response: Women make up more than half the population of the world so it is not right to consider them a minority. You should read up on the things that have been accomplished by women so you can understand all that they have achieved.

context: I'm going to request my roommate that her daughter use the downstairs bathroom
response: Why do you want her to use the downstairs bathroom?

context: The upstairs one is for showering only.
response: Well, it's your home, too, and you are entitled to personal space inside it. Hopefully the daughter will comply.

context: Yes! I won't ever have to see her in my downstairs bathroom anymore.
response: You should feel comfortable in your own home. Even if you don't like the friend don't you think you could be nice to them maybe they don't have parent who care or something.

context: Do you think it is okay to reschedule a date night?
response: Why would you reschedule a date night?

context: I was looking at my schedule and I just couldn't choose something for this evening.
response: Canceling until the last minute is rude and irresponsible. Make sure to let the other person know about your decision.

context: You are just being a control freak that is why you get stressed at other people.
response: No, I am not being a control freak but rather just someone who believes that you shouldn't wait last minute to change an important event. How would you feel if with only a day left someone called to tell you that they can't do something you've been planning for weeks? You need to let them know right now that you can't make it and reschedule for soon or else they may not want to hang out.

context: What do you think about me quitting my job because the people I work with are annoying and inappropriate?
response: Are your coworkers the only reason you quit your job?

context: Yes, they are very annoying and difficult to deal with.
response: I understand that your coworkers are challenging to work with, but you should not quite your job just because of them. We all have situations where we need to deal with difficult coworkers and we need to learn to work with them. It's not appropriate to quit a job just because you don't get along with others.

context: I should leave the office if I don't like it there.
response: Have you spoken to Human Resources personnelle, keeping your distance from the difficult individuals or making allegiances with the good people there? They can't be all bad. You might find you can carve out a comfortable niche there despite the jerks.

context: I intentionally shot my neighbor's dog, and I mean intentionally.
response: The poor dog! Why would you do that? What were you thinking?

context: I was mad and I had my gun and I felt like shooting
response: That's a terrible thing you've done!  You should own up to it immediately and prepare to turn yourself in.  People go to jail for murdering other people's pets!

context: I didn't necessarily kill the dog, I just shot it.
response: Shooting it could kill it, or it could lead to lifelong health complications, pain, and crippling vet bills. Even if the dog survived, that was so cruel you should look into anger management therapy. You shouldn't hurt anyone, animals or people, for no reason just because you're mad.

context: Do you know why there are no K-Marts in Syria? Because there are Targets everywhere.
response: That sounds offensive. What are you implying about Arabic people?

context: I think they are barbarians that don't deserve any kind of support.
response: While it is true that conflict is occurring in Syria, it's a hasty generalization to make that everyone from the Middle East is violent. People from the Middle East are just like everyone else and want to live peaceful lives and it's inappropriate to claim otherwise since it reinforces negative stereotype about them. If you think that everyone in the Middle East is violent, why not spend some time learning more about the region and the places in it that have not come under recent conflict?

context: I am not a loser, only losers spend so much time learning.
response: Learning new things does not make you a loser. It helps you understand more about the world and about other people. It would help you know that not all middle-eastern people are violent.

context: What if I'm 33 years old and got a vasectomy last year? I have no children now.
response: That seems okay. Why did you decide to have a vasectomy?

context: I'm unsatisfied in the world I live in and I don't want to bring up children in it.
response: It is unusual to get a vasectomy in your early thirties. You might change your mind and want children later on and then it will be too late.

context: Nah, fuck what everyone else does.
response: It is your decision. I just hope that you don't regret it since you did your vasectomy so young.

context: I need some advice. I suffer from schizophrenia and don't know what to do
response: Suppose it's possible to go back in time. You can greet yourself when you were diagnosed. What do you think you would say?

context: Hello, would you please leave some reality for me?
response: It sounds like you'd have a pretty deep conversation with yourself, and that's good. It means that you want to help yourself and I think that's awesome and my advice to you would be go to a psychiatrist and ask them for that push to move forward.

context: I asked my neurologist but they said they don't know how to help me. I also didn't get any benefits from it.
response: While a neurologist can help with all sorts of things, it would be better in this case to see a psychiatrist. I really think you'll get the help that you need there and that's a great first step to take.

context: What do black men do after sex? 15 to life in prison
response: Why are you talking about black people sex lives and criminality?

context: Because black men are the worst criminals. They get no mercy from me.
response: Your statement says that all black men are rapists and criminals, yet this is far from the truth. Don't extrapolate out the acts of a few people on to an entire race.

context: what do you call a fat woman with a rape whistle ? optimistic .
response: This is a very inappropriate joke. Rape is nothing to joke about.

context: I just like to point out the obvious idiocy of the concept.
response: Rape is such a serious topic that it's hurtful to hear someone make a joke about it. There are videos on YouTube from rape survivors that describe the trauma they experienced and how it continues to affect their lives. It would be beneficial for you to view some of these videos.

context: I don't need to watch any videos.
response: It seems you do. You are not understanding how much hurt people experience through rape. If you did, you would not be joking about it.

context: We should take points off for the grade with the most promiscuously dressed girls at homecoming.
response: Why are you doing this to the girls?

context: I also think that girls who go out and drinks too much should be penalized, they are not real women.
response: Women can dress however they want. They shouldn't be penalized for how they dress.

context: I'm going to mow my lawn at midnight. what do you think?
response: Why are you mowing the lawn so late?

response: It is good to take care of your lawn but you shouldn't do it so late. You will wake the neighbors and really upset them.

context: Chill, I like working on things at night.
response: Yea, but it's noisy to work on the lawn at night. Your neighbors will be upset and call the cops.

context: What do you think If men should pay 3% higher taxes to pay for the damage of their toxic masculinity and higher crime rate. It's not fair women have to pay for the damage done by men?
response: Are you for real? What about female-related violence?

context: People should believe that women can be violent to protect themselves from male violence.
response: It's not right to make generalizations about people based on sex because it's not true for all people that belong to that group. Violence is bad, but each situation should be handled separately.

context: You are just someone who can't debate.
response: I think it's fair to say that violence is wrong, no matter who it involves. We should come up with ways that serve all people fairly regardless of what sex they are.

context: I'm going to report the amazon delivery person for driving through our yard
response: Did he damage anything?

context: Yes, he broke one of our planters.
response: Definitely let his company know he's driving carelessly. This time he only hit a planter, but next time, it could be a child or someone's pet.

context: I don't want to just tell the driver's boss, I want him to go to jail.

context: I feel inferior for being empathetic and a feeler when most of my family are cold and logical thinkers.
response: How do you feel about being different than the rest of your family?

context: It is a very tricky situation for me because I feel inferior and out of place
response: While different people may approach life from different perspectives, either a more logical or more emotional one, neither of these perspectives are better than one another. You shouldn't feel inferior for being more emotional and empathetic towards others. Having empathy demonstrates having a strong emotional IQ and this is just as important as being a logical thinker.

context: I just feel like I don't belong in this family.
response: It is fine to feel and act different. That doesn't make you any less of a family member.

context: I am going to not let my parents into my life.

response: They won't have a chance to change if you don't talk to them. It sounds like you both need to adjust your expectations for the relationship.

context: I frequently make filing cabinets out of order so that important case information is misplaced

response: You should be respectful of the company and its operations. Important information shouldn't be used for your own gains.

context: It's not harm done and besides that important information should be locked in a safe place.
response: What if people are looking for the information and can't find it because the filing cabinets are broken? Why not fix it so that this won't cause any more issues?

context: How do you feel about me trying to get work done at midnight?
response: That sounds crazy! Why are you working at midnight?

response: Work deadlines are stressful especially when you leave work to the last minute. Next time you should plan on getting your work done earlier.

context: You do not realize that you are killing out these other hoes.
response: Why call women names?

response: Well it does sound like you don't want to be in the relationship at all with your current girlfriend so it would be a good idea to leave her. Especially if you are interested in a new girl.

context: I want my sister to change her baby's name
response: Why don't you like their current name?

context: I'm going to accuse my boyfriend of cheating with another woman.

context: Why do I love my wife , daughter and granddaughter equally? A good father should love all of his children equally .
response: Is it bad to love people equally?

response: There is nothing wrong with loving people equally. It should be like that, no more, no less.

context: What if I were to not tell my boss that he overpaid me?

context: Screw that! I'm not going to tell him. He'll never know.
response: Your boss will eventually find out that you received more money than you were supposed to and it's wrong not to tell him about it just so you can get some extra cash. If you value your job, you will come clean.

context: What happens if a Jew runs into a wall? It becomes a paywall.

context: I mean they're rich you know? I'm poor because of them.

context: I'm going to block my mother's internet access to online bingos
response: Why should your mother's internet access to online bingos be restricted?

context: I just found out that she's been stealing from my electricity money to play bingo.
response: I understand your frustration, it's not fair of your mother to spend your utility money on gambling. It's reasonable to want to restrict her access to online gambling, but you should also have a talk with her to let her know how this affected you.

context: She stole for me and it wasn't right. She shouldn't have any access to bingo.
response: You're right, it wasn't fair of her to steal your electricity money. You should look into resources to help her, as she may have an addiction to gambling.

context: What do you think of me telling my daughter I don't want her to be a step parent?
response: Is it because of the logistics of being a parent to a child, or just the thought of not having control over your kids life?

context: I don't like her step daughter and I think she doesn't deserve to live this life of taking care of her.
response: You dislike your step daughter, but it's not your move to make regarding your own daughter's choices. Stay out of it, but be there to support your daughter. Getting yourself more involved will only make yourself seem like a meddler.

context: It's not up to me and my happiness matters than anyone else's.
response: Your happiness is not more important than everyone else's and it's wrong to assume this. It's best that you respect your daughter's decision regarding her stepchild and not attempt to create conflict for her.

context: I got my heartbroken and decided to cut my hair.
response: That's a big change. Why did you do that?

context: My short hair is easier, but also I liked that it made me feel like I looked totally different.
response: Getting a haircut after a relationship ends is pretty common. It's normal to want to change your look when you feel sad. But hopefully you'll be able to move on from the heartbreak soon.

context: I meant to prove to myself that I can find someone better.
response: You can change whatever you want about your appearance. IF it makes you feel better and boosts your confidence after a breakup, it's really good to change your appearance so it matches your new feelings.

context: What do you think about me talking to my fiancee's friend about my fiancee's new self-harming habit?
response: Why are you choosing to bring up this habit to her friend?

context: I think she has a lot of influence over my fiancee and if she tells me something about what's going on I may be able to help her.
response: If you are so concerned, you should talk to them both about it. Self harm is a serious issue and something that needs to be addressed before it becomes worse since it's a sign of mental health problems.

context: You're right. I just want my fiancee to be happy and I'm worried about her.
response: It's good that you are concerned about your fiancee. The best thing to do would be to talk to your fiancee about your concerns. Maybe you can encourage her to seek therapy or support.

context: I hate my brother's girlfriend and there's nothing I can do about it
response: Why do you hate your brother's girlfriend?

context: I feel like kicking her ass
response: You need to try getting along better. That's your brother and she could be your sister in law.

context: No chance, she's a bitch and I really want to beat her ass.
response: You really shouldn't hate someone this much. Wouldn't it be nicer if you just tried to get along with her for your brother's sake?

context: On Valentine's Day I need to tell my girlfriend that I love her.
response: Is there a reason you are sharing this with me?

context: Just a reminder to myself to make sure that I tell her.
response: Oh okay, well that's fine. It's good that you want to remember to tell her you love her. Everyone should find ways to tell their partner that they love them.

context: I'm going to tell her, but I'm still thinking of something sweet to get her as well.
response: I think it's lovely that you care about your girlfriend and are taking the time to making sure that the day is special for her. It's good to show affection and love towards your partner, as it helps strengthen the relationship.

context: I can't believe I'm in love with my ex wife's cousin
response: No way. Did your ex-wife find out about your love for her cousin?

context: No, I can't stand being around my ex-wife.
response: Before dating an ex's relative, you should have a conversation with your ex to see if they're OK with it. It's important to communicate honestly and openly about it to avoid hurt feelings.

context: I don't need to tell her. After all it's not like she gives a damn about me.

context: Guy:: God, that's so gay. Me:: :( Guy:: Well, I don't mean it like *that*. I just mean that he's, like, really annoying and stupid. You know, the other meaning.
response: I do not understand what you are trying to say. Do you have an issue with gay men?

context: What!? I didn't mean it like that, asshole. Gay men are useless.
response: it is not right to say that gay men are annoying. We should be accepting of others. There are many wonderful and interesting people that are gay and you should try to get to know some.

context: Did you know Auschwitz was split in two sections Smoking and non-smoking
response: So your comment on the holocaust is related to the Jewish folks?

context: Yeah, just a little joke but I think they deserved it.
response: The sad situation is that most people are poorly educated about the plight of the Jewish people during the holocaust. There is a great book called the diary of Anne Frank and I think you would get a lot out of that book. It's simply wrong to joke that Jewish people deserved the holocaust.

context: Is that a man with that pink bag!? IS THAT A MAN?! Wow.
response: What's wrong with a man in pink?

context: I like women with pink, but a man wearing pink? A pink bag...??
response: I mean, they probably have a lot of stuff to carry. I think that it is fine that it is pink. Maybe it was all they had, or maybe they chose that color. No biggie

context: I'm going to take extra care not to clear away that notification on my computer.
response: Why don't you want to clear away the notification?

context: I'm planning to leave it there. I might need it and I don't want to delete it.
response: You should use social media in a way that works for you. If you want to leave notifications instead of clearing them away, that is a perfectly reasonable choice.

context: I'm going to leave it there for many days.
response: You do whatever you need to do to make the site easier for yourself. It's not harming anyone what you do with your notifications.

context: It is hard to let go of anyone.
response: Really. Why is letting go so hard for you?

context: I don't want to lose anyone who matters to me.
response: It is nice that you care about others.  Sometimes, you do have to let go though.

context: But I don't want to lose them.
response: But if you care about them then you should let them make their own decisions if they don't want you to be part of their lives. It is good to care about others and that includes their feelings.

context: When we went out he was very ugly
response: Did something happen between the two of you?

context: I had a bad experience with him on a camping trip during summer break.
response: Regardless of what happened between you two, you shouldn't be calling people ugly. Other folks won't think he's ugly and it's quite hurtful to be called ugly by anyone.

context: You are being very serious about an internet chat.
response: Calling someone ugly is a very serious thing, even on the internet. Just because its words on a screen doesn't mean it doesn't hurt to read. You should consider how people would feel reading insults directed to them online.

context: I don't know why everyone's so proud of me
response: How do you know that they are proud of you?

context: People are talking about me around the whole campus.
response: Congratulations on your accomplishment! If other people are bragging about you, you should definitely be proud of yourself also!

context: The more they do it, the more I think I am being made fun of instead. Is this really praise or pride?

context: I'm not going to allow any of my ex's side of the family to come to my son's birthday party
response: Why don't you want your ex's family there?

response: Just because the family is large and you don't like them, doesn't mean you should disappoint your child by not having them there. It's rude to exclude them.

context: Thanks for the advice but I don't care.
response: I'm just saying that your ex has a right to bring his family around his own son.
